   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
          <b>
           Motto:
          </b>
          <br/>
          <i>
           <span lang="es">
            "¡Patria o Muerte, Venceremos!"
           </span>
          </i>
          <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">
           (Spanish)
          </span>
          <br/>
          <small>
           "Homeland or Death, we shall overcome!"
          </small>
          <span style="position: relative; top: 0.2em;">
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-1">
             [1]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
          <br/>
          •
          <br/>
          "
          <i>
           <span lang="es">
            <a href="/wiki/Workers_of_the_world,_unite!" title="Workers of the world, unite!">
             ¡Trabajadores del mundo, únanse!
            </a>
           </span>
          </i>
          "
          <br/>
          <small>
           "Workers of the world, unite!"
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>

        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Raúl Castro">
          Raúl Castro
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>

         </a>
        </td>

            From 1993 to 2004, the
            <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">
             United States dollar
            </a>
            was used alongside the peso until the dollar was replaced by the convertible peso.
           </li>
          </ol>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Cuba
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
            k
           </span>
           <span title="/juː/: 'u' in 'cute'">
            juː
           </span>
           <span title="'b' in 'buy'">
            b
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
       ;
       <small>
        Spanish pronunciation:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">
         [ˈkuβa]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Cuba
       </b>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       :
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RCUB.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/28/Rep%C3%BAblica_de_Cuba.ogg" title="República de Cuba.ogg">
          <span class="unicode" lang="es">
           <i>
            República de Cuba
           </i>
          </span>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/File:RCUB.ogg" title="File:RCUB.ogg">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ), is a country comprising the island of Cuba as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_la_Juventud" title="Isla de la Juventud">
        Isla de la Juventud
       </a>
       and several minor
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archipelagos" title="Archipelagos">
        archipelagos
       </a>
       . Cuba is located in the northern
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       where the
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">
        Caribbean Sea
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">
        Gulf of Mexico
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">
        Atlantic Ocean
       </a>
       meet. It is south of both the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        U.S.
       </a>
       state of
       <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">
        Florida
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bahamas" title="The Bahamas">
        the Bahamas
       </a>
       , west of
       <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">
        Haiti
       </a>
       , and north of
       <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">
        Jamaica
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">
        Havana
       </a>
       is the largest city and capital; other major cities include
       <a href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Cuba" title="Santiago de Cuba">
        Santiago de Cuba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Camag%C3%BCey" title="Camagüey">
        Camagüey
       </a>
       . Cuba is the largest island in the Caribbean, with an area of 109,884 square kilometres (42,426 sq mi), and the second-most populous after
       <a href="/wiki/Hispaniola" title="Hispaniola">
        Hispaniola
       </a>
       , with over 11 million inhabitants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_profile_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC_profile-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The territory of Cuba was inhabited by the Ciboney tribes in the
       <a href="/wiki/4th_millennium_BC" title="4th millennium BC">
        4th millennium BC
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Until the 15th century, it was inhabited by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian" title="Amerindian">
        Amerindian
       </a>
       tribes which became a colony of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spain
       </a>
       until the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">
        Spanish–American War
       </a>
       of 1898, when Cuba gained
       <a href="/wiki/Platt_Amendment" title="Platt Amendment">
        nominal independence
       </a>
       as a
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        United States
       </a>
       protectorate in 1902. As a fragile republic, Cuba attempted to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_Constitution_of_1940" title="Cuban Constitution of 1940">
        strengthen its democratic system
       </a>
       , but mounting political radicalization and social strife culminated in the dictatorship of
       <a href="/wiki/Fulgencio_Batista" title="Fulgencio Batista">
        Fulgencio Batista
       </a>
       in 1952.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Further unrest and instability led to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_revolution" title="Cuban revolution">
        Batista's ousting in January 1959
       </a>
       by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/July_26_Movement" title="July 26 Movement">
        July 26 Movement
       </a>
       , which afterwards established communist rule under the leadership of
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">
        Fidel Castro
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica-castro_16-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-britannica-castro-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gonzalo-castro_17-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gonzalo-castro-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dw-castro_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-dw-castro-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 1965, the state has been governed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Cuba" title="Communist Party of Cuba">
        Communist Party of Cuba
       </a>
       . A point of contention during the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       between the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       and the United States, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_war" title="Nuclear war">
        nuclear war
       </a>
       nearly broke out during the
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">
        Cuban Missile Crisis
       </a>
       of 1962. Cuba is one of the few remaining
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxist%E2%80%93Leninist" title="Marxist–Leninist">
        Marxist–Leninist
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">
        socialist states
       </a>
       , where the role of the vanguard Communist Party is enshrined in the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Cuba" title="Constitution of Cuba">
        Constitution
       </a>
       . Independent observers have accused the Cuban government of numerous
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">
        human rights
       </a>
       abuses, including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arbitrary_imprisonment" title="Arbitrary imprisonment">
        arbitrary imprisonment
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Culturally, Cuba is considered part of
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multiethnic" title="Multiethnic">
        multiethnic
       </a>
       country whose
       <a href="/wiki/Cubans" title="Cubans">
        people
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Cuba" title="Culture of Cuba">
        culture
       </a>
       and customs derive from diverse origins, including the aboriginal
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people" title="Taíno people">
        Taíno
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ciboney" title="Ciboney">
        Ciboney
       </a>
       peoples, the long period of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish colonialism
       </a>
       , the introduction of
       <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_Spanish_New_World_colonies" title="Slavery in the Spanish New World colonies">
        African slaves
       </a>
       , and a close
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuba-Soviet_relations" title="Cuba-Soviet relations">
        relationship with the Soviet Union
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba is a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        UN
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">
        G77
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        NAM
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/African,_Caribbean_and_Pacific_Group_of_States" title="African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States">
        ACP
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/ALBA" title="ALBA">
        ALBA
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        OAS
       </a>
       . The country is one of the world's only
       <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">
        planned economies
       </a>
       and its
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Cuba" title="Economy of Cuba">
        economy
       </a>
       is dominated by the exports of sugar, tobacco, coffee and skilled labor. According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       , Cuba has high human development and is ranked the eighth highest in North America, though 67th in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It also ranks highly in some metrics of national performance, including
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba#Health" title="Cuba">
        health care
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba#Education" title="Cuba">
        education
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is the only country in the world to receive
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">
        WWF
       </a>
       's definition of sustainable development.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Historians believe the name
       <i>
        Cuba
       </i>
       comes from the
       <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_language" title="Taíno language">
        Taíno language
       </a>
       , however "its exact derivation [is] unknown".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The exact meaning of the name is unclear but it may be translated either as 'where fertile land is abundant' (
       <i>
        cubao
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or 'great place' (
       <i>
        coabana
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Authors who believe that
       <a href="/wiki/Origin_theories_of_Christopher_Columbus" title="Origin theories of Christopher Columbus">
        Christopher Columbus was Portuguese
       </a>
       state that
       <i>
        Cuba
       </i>
       was named by Columbus for the
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba,_Portugal" title="Cuba, Portugal">
        town of Cuba
       </a>
       in the district of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beja_(Portugal)" title="Beja (Portugal)">
        Beja
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">
        Portugal
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Cuba" title="History of Cuba">
        History of Cuba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Cuban_history" title="Timeline of Cuban history">
        Timeline of Cuban history
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_era">
        Pre-Columbian era
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hatuey_monument,_Baracoa,_Cuba.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2272" data-file-width="1515" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG/170px-Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG/255px-Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG/340px-Hatuey_monument%2C_Baracoa%2C_Cuba.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hatuey_monument,_Baracoa,_Cuba.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Monument of
         <a href="/wiki/Hatuey" title="Hatuey">
          Hatuey
         </a>
         , an early
         <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Taíno">
          Taíno
         </a>
         chief of Cuba
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Before the arrival of the Spanish, Cuba was inhabited by three distinct tribes of
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">
        indigenous peoples of the Americas
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people" title="Taíno people">
        Taíno
       </a>
       (an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arawak_peoples" title="Arawak peoples">
        Arawak
       </a>
       people), the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guanajatabey" title="Guanajatabey">
        Guanajatabey
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ciboney_people" title="Ciboney people">
        Ciboney people
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The ancestors of the Ciboney migrated from the mainland of South America, with the earliest sites dated to 5,000
       <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">
        BP
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnAofPCC_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AnAofPCC-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Taíno arrived from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hispanola" title="Hispanola">
        Hispanola
       </a>
       sometime in the 3rd century A.D. When Columbus arrived they were the dominant culture in Cuba, having an estimated population of 150,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnAofPCC_29-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-AnAofPCC-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Taíno were farmers, while the Ciboney were farmers as well as fishers and
       <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">
        hunter-gatherers
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Spanish_colonization_and_rule_.281492.E2.80.931898.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_colonization_and_rule_(1492–1898)">
        Spanish colonization and rule (1492–1898)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Cuba" title="Captaincy General of Cuba">
        Captaincy General of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       After first landing on an island then called
       <a href="/wiki/Guanahani" title="Guanahani">
        Guanahani
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bahamas" title="Bahamas">
        Bahamas
       </a>
       , on 12 October 1492,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Henken2008_30-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Henken2008-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
        Christopher Columbus
       </a>
       commanded his three ships:
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Pinta_(ship)" title="Pinta (ship)">
         La Pinta
        </a>
        ,
       </i>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ni%C3%B1a" title="Niña">
         La Niña
        </a>
       </i>
       and the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_(ship)" title="Santa María (ship)">
         Santa María
        </a>
        ,
       </i>
       to land on Cuba's northeastern coast on 28 October 1492.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (This was near what is now Bariay,
       <a href="/wiki/Holgu%C3%ADn_Province" title="Holguín Province">
        Holguín Province
       </a>
       .) Columbus claimed the island for the new Kingdom of
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gott_p13_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gott_p13-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and named it
       <i>
        Isla Juana
       </i>
       after
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juan,_Prince_of_Asturias" title="Juan, Prince of Asturias">
        Juan, Prince of Asturias
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2075" data-file-width="1615" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg/170px-DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg/255px-DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg/340px-DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DiegoVelazquezCuellar.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez_de_Cu%C3%A9llar" title="Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar">
          Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">
          conquistador
         </a>
         of Cuba
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1511, the first Spanish settlement was founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez_de_Cu%C3%A9llar" title="Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar">
        Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/Baracoa" title="Baracoa">
        Baracoa
       </a>
       . Other towns soon followed, including
       <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">
        San Cristobal de la Habana
       </a>
       , founded in 1515, which later became the capital. The native Taíno were forced to work under the
       <a href="/wiki/Encomienda" title="Encomienda">
        encomienda
       </a>
       system,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which resembled a
       <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">
        feudal system
       </a>
       in Medieval Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAlister_1984_164_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-McAlister_1984_164-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Within a century the indigenous people were virtually wiped out due to multiple factors, primarily Eurasian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infectious_disease" title="Infectious disease">
        infectious diseases
       </a>
       , to which they had no natural resistance (immunity), aggravated by harsh conditions of the repressive colonial subjugation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1529, a
       <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">
        measles
       </a>
       outbreak in Cuba killed two-thirds of those few natives who had previously survived
       <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">
        smallpox
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 18 May 1539, Conquistador
       <a href="/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto" title="Hernando de Soto">
        Hernando de Soto
       </a>
       departed from Havana at the head of some 600 followers into a vast expedition through the Southeastern United States, starting at La
       <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">
        Florida
       </a>
       , in search of gold, treasure, fame and power.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 1 September 1548, Dr. Gonzalo Perez de Angulo was appointed governor of Cuba. He arrived in Santiago, Cuba on 4 November 1549 and immediately declared the liberty of all natives.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_1916_183_40-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wright_1916_183-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He became Cuba's first permanent governor to reside in Havana instead of Santiago, and he built Havana's first church made of masonry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_1916_229_41-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wright_1916_229-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the French took Havana in 1555, the governor's son, Francisco de Angulo, went to Mexico.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_1916_246_42-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wright_1916_246-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="629" data-file-width="1486" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png/350px-Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png/525px-Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png/700px-Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png 2x" width="350"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Darlington_map_of_Cuba_1680.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         British map of Cuba 1680
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba developed slowly and, unlike the plantation islands of the Caribbean, had a diversified agriculture. But what was most important was that the colony developed as an urbanized society that primarily supported the Spanish colonial empire. By the mid-18th century, its colonists held 50,000 slaves, compared to 60,000 in
       <a href="/wiki/Barbados" title="Barbados">
        Barbados
       </a>
       ; 300,000 in
       <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Virginia" title="Colony of Virginia">
        Virginia
       </a>
       , both British colonies; and 450,000 in French
       <a href="/wiki/Saint-Domingue" title="Saint-Domingue">
        Saint-Domingue
       </a>
       , which had large-scale sugar cane plantations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4799" data-file-width="6234" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif/lossy-page1-220px-Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif/lossy-page1-330px-Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif/lossy-page1-440px-Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Descriptionis_Ptolemaic%C3%A6_avgmentvm_siue_Occidentis_notitia_breui_commentario_illustrata_p193.tif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Map of Cuba by Cornelius van Wytfliet in 1597 (National Library of Sweden)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">
        Seven Years' War
       </a>
       , which erupted in 1754 across three continents, eventually arrived in the Spanish Caribbean. Spain's alliance with the French pitched them into direct conflict with the British, and in 1762
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Havana_(1762)" title="Battle of Havana (1762)">
        a British expedition
       </a>
       of five warships and 4,000 troops set out from
       <a href="/wiki/Portsmouth" title="Portsmouth">
        Portsmouth
       </a>
       to capture Cuba. The British arrived on 6 June, and by August had Havana under
       <a href="/wiki/Siege" title="Siege">
        siege
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siege_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Siege-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When Havana surrendered, the admiral of the British fleet,
       <a href="/wiki/George_Keppel,_3rd_Earl_of_Albemarle" title="George Keppel, 3rd Earl of Albemarle">
        George Keppel
       </a>
       , the 3rd
       <a href="/wiki/Earl_of_Albemarle" title="Earl of Albemarle">
        Earl of Albemarle
       </a>
       , entered the city as a conquering new governor and took control of the whole western part of the island. The British immediately opened up trade with their North American and Caribbean colonies, causing a rapid transformation of Cuban society. They imported food, horses and other goods into the city, as well as thousands of slaves from West Africa to work on the under developed sugar plantations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siege_44-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Siege-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LindsayCambridge.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="952" data-file-width="1280" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/LindsayCambridge.jpg/220px-LindsayCambridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/LindsayCambridge.jpg/330px-LindsayCambridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/LindsayCambridge.jpg/440px-LindsayCambridge.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LindsayCambridge.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_expedition_against_Cuba" title="British expedition against Cuba">
          British invasion and occupation of Havana
         </a>
         in 1762
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Though Havana, which had become the third-largest city in the Americas, was to enter an era of sustained development and increasing ties with North America during this period, the British occupation of the city proved short-lived. Pressure from London sugar merchants, fearing a decline in sugar prices, forced negotiations with the Spanish over colonial territories. Less than a year after Britain seized Havana, it signed the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763)" title="Treaty of Paris (1763)">
        Peace of Paris
       </a>
       together with France and Spain, ending the Seven Years' War. The treaty gave Britain
       <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">
        Florida
       </a>
       in exchange for Cuba. The French had recommended this to Spain, advising that declining to give up Florida could result in Spain instead losing Mexico and much of the South American mainland to the British.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siege_44-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Siege-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many in Britain were disappointed, believing that Florida was a poor return for Cuba and
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain_in_the_Seven_Years%27_War" title="Great Britain in the Seven Years' War">
        Britain's other gains in the war
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The real engine for the growth of Cuba's commerce in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century was the
       <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Revolution" title="Haitian Revolution">
        Haitian Revolution
       </a>
       . When the enslaved peoples of what had been the Caribbean's richest colony freed themselves through violent revolt, Cuban planters perceived the region's changing circumstances with both a sense of fear and opportunity. They were afraid because of the prospect that slaves might revolt in Cuba, too, and numerous prohibitions during the 1790s on the sale of slaves in Cuba that had previously been slaves in French colonies underscored this anxiety. The planters saw opportunity, however, because they thought that they could exploit the situation by transforming Cuba into the slave society and sugar-producing "pearl of the Antilles" that Haiti had been before the revolution.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As the historian Ada Ferrer has written, "At a basic level, liberation in Saint-Domingue helped entrench its denial in Cuba. As slavery and colonialism collapsed in the French colony, the Spanish island underwent transformations that were almost the mirror image of Haiti's."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estimates suggest that between 1790 and 1820 some 325,000 Africans were imported to Cuba as slaves, which was four times the amount that had arrived between 1760 and 1790.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1539" data-file-width="2382" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg/220px-Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg/330px-Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg/440px-Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slaves_Unloading_Ice_in_Cuba_1832.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">
          Slaves
         </a>
         in Cuba unloading ice from Maine,
         <abbr title="circa">
          c.
         </abbr>
         <span style="white-space:nowrap;">
          1832
         </span>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Although a smaller proportion of the population of Cuba was enslaved, at times slaves arose in revolt. In 1812 the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aponte_Conspiracy" title="Aponte Conspiracy">
        Aponte Slave Rebellion
       </a>
       took place but it was suppressed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The population of Cuba in 1817 was 630,980, of which 291,021 were white, 115,691
       <a href="/wiki/Free_people_of_color" title="Free people of color">
        free people of color
       </a>
       (mixed-race), and 224,268 black slaves.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scheina_2003_352_49-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Scheina_2003_352-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This was a much higher proportion of free blacks to slaves than in
       <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">
        Virginia
       </a>
       , for instance, or the other Caribbean islands. Historians such as Swedish Magnus Mõrner, who studied slavery in Latin America, found that
       <a href="/wiki/Manumission" title="Manumission">
        manumissions
       </a>
       increased when slave economies were in decline, as in 18th-century Cuba and early 19th-century Maryland of the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In part due to Cuban slaves working primarily in urbanized settings, by the 19th century, there had developed the practice of
       <i>
        coartacion
       </i>
       , or "buying oneself out of slavery", a "uniquely Cuban development", according to historian Herbert S. Klein.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Due to a shortage of white labor, blacks dominated urban industries "to such an extent that when whites in large numbers came to Cuba in the middle of the nineteenth century, they were unable to displace Negro workers."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A system of diversified agriculture, with small farms and fewer slaves, served to supply the cities with produce and other goods.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 1820s, when the rest of Spain's empire in
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       rebelled and formed independent states, Cuba remained loyal. Its economy was based on serving the empire.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title="The text near this tag needs further explanation. (December 2017)">
           further explanation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       By 1860, Cuba had 213,167 free people of color, 39% of its non-white population of 550,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By contrast, Virginia, with about the same number of blacks, had only 58,042 or 11% who were free; the rest were enslaved.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drimmer_43-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-drimmer-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the antebellum years, Virginia discouraged manumissions after
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nat_Turner%27s_Slave_Rebellion" title="Nat Turner's Slave Rebellion">
        Nat Turner's Slave Rebellion
       </a>
       of 1831 and strengthened restrictions against free blacks, as did other Southern states. In addition, there was a high demand for slaves, and Virginia planters sold many in the internal domestic slave trade, to be shipped or taken overland to the
       <a href="/wiki/Deep_South" title="Deep South">
        Deep South
       </a>
       , which had greatly expanded its cotton production.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_movements">
        Independence movements
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_War_of_Independence" title="Cuban War of Independence">
        Cuban War of Independence
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="391" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg/170px-Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg/255px-Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg/340px-Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Manuel_de_Cespedes.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Manuel_de_C%C3%A9spedes" title="Carlos Manuel de Céspedes">
          Carlos Manuel de Céspedes
         </a>
         is known as
         <i>
          Father of the Homeland
         </i>
         in Cuba, having declared the nation's independence from Spain in 1868.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Full independence from Spain was the goal of a rebellion in 1868 led by planter
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Manuel_de_C%C3%A9spedes" title="Carlos Manuel de Céspedes">
        Carlos Manuel de Céspedes
       </a>
       . De Céspedes, a sugar planter, freed his slaves to fight with him for an independent Cuba. On 27 December 1868, he issued a decree condemning slavery in theory but accepting it in practice and declaring free any slaves whose masters present them for military service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChomskyCarrSmorkaloff2004[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sr2hQkCIihMC&amp;pg=PA115_115–7]_52-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChomskyCarrSmorkaloff2004[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sr2hQkCIihMC&amp;pg=PA115_115–7]-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 1868 rebellion resulted in a prolonged conflict known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Ten_Years%27_War" title="Ten Years' War">
        Ten Years' War
       </a>
       . Two thousand Cuban Chinese joined the rebels. Chinese had been imported as indentured laborers. A monument in Havana honours the Cuban Chinese who fell in the war.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The United States declined to recognize the new Cuban government, although many European and Latin American nations did so.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1878, the
       <a href="/wiki/Pact_of_Zanj%C3%B3n" title="Pact of Zanjón">
        Pact of Zanjón
       </a>
       ended the conflict, with Spain promising greater autonomy to Cuba. In 1879–1880, Cuban patriot
       <a href="/wiki/Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa" title="Calixto García">
        Calixto García
       </a>
       attempted to start another war known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Little_War_(Cuba)" title="Little War (Cuba)">
        Little War
       </a>
       but did not receive enough support.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Cuba" title="Slavery in Cuba">
        Slavery in Cuba
       </a>
       was abolished in 1875 but the process was completed only in 1886.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott_2000_3_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Scott_2000_3-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChomskyCarrSmorkaloff2004[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sr2hQkCIihMC&amp;pg=PA37_37–8]_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChomskyCarrSmorkaloff2004[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sr2hQkCIihMC&amp;pg=PA37_37–8]-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       An exiled dissident named
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mart%C3%AD" title="José Martí">
        José Martí
       </a>
       founded the Cuban Revolutionary Party in
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
        New York
       </a>
       in 1892. The aim of the party was to achieve Cuban independence from Spain.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandler_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sandler-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 1895 Martí traveled to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Fernando_de_Monte_Cristi" title="San Fernando de Monte Cristi">
        Montecristi
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Santo_Domingo" title="Santo Domingo">
        Santo Domingo
       </a>
       to join the efforts of
       <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1ximo_G%C3%B3mez" title="Máximo Gómez">
        Máximo Gómez
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandler_58-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-sandler-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Martí recorded his political views in the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Manifesto_of_Montecristi" title="Manifesto of Montecristi">
         Manifesto of Montecristi
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arias_59-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-arias-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fighting against the Spanish army began in Cuba on 24 February 1895, but Martí was unable to reach Cuba until 11 April 1895.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandler_58-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-sandler-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Martí was killed in the battle of Dos Rios on 19 May 1895.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandler_58-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-sandler-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His death immortalized him as Cuba's national hero.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arias_59-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-arias-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba,_1898.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="912" data-file-width="960" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg/220px-Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg/330px-Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg/440px-Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba%2C_1898.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa_and_William_Ludlow_in_Cuba,_1898.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Calixto_Garc%C3%ADa" title="Calixto García">
          Calixto García
         </a>
         , a general of Cuban separatist rebels, (right) with U.S. Brigadier General
         <a href="/wiki/William_Ludlow" title="William Ludlow">
          William Ludlow
         </a>
         (Cuba, 1898)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Around 200,000 Spanish troops outnumbered the much smaller rebel army, which relied mostly on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guerrilla" title="Guerrilla">
        guerrilla
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sabotage" title="Sabotage">
        sabotage
       </a>
       tactics. The Spaniards began a campaign of suppression. General
       <a href="/wiki/Valeriano_Weyler" title="Valeriano Weyler">
        Valeriano Weyler
       </a>
       , military governor of Cuba, herded the rural population into what he called
       <i>
        reconcentrados
       </i>
       , described by international observers as "fortified towns". These are often considered the prototype for 20th-century
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concentration_camp" title="Concentration camp">
        concentration camps
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 200,000 and 400,000 Cuban civilians died from starvation and disease in the camps, numbers verified by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Cross" title="Red Cross">
        Red Cross
       </a>
       and United States Senator
       <a href="/wiki/Redfield_Proctor" title="Redfield Proctor">
        Redfield Proctor
       </a>
       , a former
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War" title="United States Secretary of War">
        Secretary of War
       </a>
       . American and European protests against Spanish conduct on the island followed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The U.S. battleship
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/USS_Maine_(ACR-1)" title="USS Maine (ACR-1)">
         Maine
        </a>
       </i>
       was sent to protect U.S. interests, but soon after arrival, it exploded in Havana harbor and sank quickly, killing nearly three quarters of the crew. The cause and responsibility for the sinking of the ship remained unclear after a board of inquiry. Popular opinion in the U.S., fueled by an active press, concluded that the Spanish were to blame and demanded action.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morison_62-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-morison-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spain and the United States declared war on each other in late April 1898.
      </p>
      <p>
       Over the previous decades, five U.S. presidents—
       <a href="/wiki/James_K._Polk" title="James K. Polk">
        Polk
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Pierce" title="Franklin Pierce">
        Pierce
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/James_Buchanan" title="James Buchanan">
        Buchanan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Ulysses S. Grant">
        Grant
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/William_McKinley" title="William McKinley">
        McKinley
       </a>
       —had tried to buy the island of Cuba from Spain.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falk_1998_64_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Falk_1998_64-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Republic_.281902.E2.80.9359.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_(1902–59)">
        Republic (1902–59)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Cuba_(1902%E2%80%9359)" title="History of Cuba (1902–59)">
        History of Cuba (1902–59)
       </a>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span id="First_years_.281902.E2.80.931925.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_years_(1902–1925)">
        First years (1902–1925)
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20,_1902.gif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="720" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif/220px-Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif/330px-Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif/440px-Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20%2C_1902.gif 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Raising_the_Cuban_flag_on_the_Governor_General%27s_Palace_at_noon_on_May_20,_1902.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Raising the Cuban flag on the Governor General's Palace at noon on 20 May 1902
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">
        Spanish–American War
       </a>
       , Spain and the United States signed the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">
        Treaty of Paris (1898)
       </a>
       , by which Spain ceded
       <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">
        Puerto Rico
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">
        Philippines
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">
        Guam
       </a>
       to the United States for the sum of
       <span class="nowrap">
        US$20 million
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba gained formal independence from the U.S. on 20 May 1902, as the Republic of Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pérez1998_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pérez1998-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under Cuba's new constitution, the U.S. retained the right to intervene in Cuban affairs and to supervise its finances and foreign relations. Under the
       <a href="/wiki/Platt_Amendment" title="Platt Amendment">
        Platt Amendment
       </a>
       , the U.S. leased the
       <a href="/wiki/Guant%C3%A1namo_Bay" title="Guantánamo Bay">
        Guantánamo Bay
       </a>
       naval base from Cuba.
      </p>
      <p>
       Following disputed elections in 1906, the first president,
       <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Estrada_Palma" title="Tomás Estrada Palma">
        Tomás Estrada Palma
       </a>
       , faced an armed revolt by independence war veterans who defeated the meager government forces.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The U.S. intervened by occupying Cuba and named
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Edward_Magoon" title="Charles Edward Magoon">
        Charles Edward Magoon
       </a>
       as Governor for three years. Cuban historians have characterized Magoon's governorship as having introduced political and social corruption.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thomas_1998_283to287_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Thomas_1998_283to287-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1908, self-government was restored when
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Miguel_G%C3%B3mez" title="José Miguel Gómez">
        José Miguel Gómez
       </a>
       was elected President, but the U.S. continued intervening in Cuban affairs. In 1912, the
       <a href="/wiki/Partido_Independiente_de_Color" title="Partido Independiente de Color">
        Partido Independiente de Color
       </a>
       attempted to establish a separate black republic in Oriente Province,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but was suppressed by General Monteagudo with considerable bloodshed.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1924,
       <a href="/wiki/Gerardo_Machado" title="Gerardo Machado">
        Gerardo Machado
       </a>
       was elected president.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-D2012_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-D2012-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During his administration, tourism increased markedly, and American-owned hotels and restaurants were built to accommodate the influx of tourists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-D2012_70-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-D2012-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The tourist boom led to increases in gambling and
       <a href="/wiki/Prostitution_in_Cuba" title="Prostitution in Cuba">
        prostitution in Cuba
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-D2012_70-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-D2012-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929" title="Wall Street Crash of 1929">
        Wall Street Crash of 1929
       </a>
       led to a collapse in the price of sugar, political unrest, and repression.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChaffeePrevost1992_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ChaffeePrevost1992-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Protesting students, known as the Generation of 1930, turned to violence in opposition to the increasingly unpopular Machado.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChaffeePrevost1992_71-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ChaffeePrevost1992-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A general strike (in which the Communist Party sided with Machado),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       uprisings among sugar workers, and an army revolt forced Machado into exile in August 1933. He was replaced by
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Manuel_de_C%C3%A9spedes_y_Quesada" title="Carlos Manuel de Céspedes y Quesada">
        Carlos Manuel de Céspedes y Quesada
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChaffeePrevost1992_71-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-ChaffeePrevost1992-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="611" data-file-width="1000" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg/220px-1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg/330px-1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg/440px-1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1933-Pentarchy_w_Batista.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy_of_1933" title="Pentarchy of 1933">
          Pentarchy of 1933
         </a>
         .
         <a href="/wiki/Fulgencio_Batista" title="Fulgencio Batista">
          Fulgencio Batista
         </a>
         , who controlled the armed forces, appears at far right
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span id="Revolution_of_1933.E2.80.931940">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Revolution_of_1933–1940">
        Revolution of 1933–1940
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In September 1933, the Sergeants' Revolt, led by Sergeant
       <a href="/wiki/Fulgencio_Batista" title="Fulgencio Batista">
        Fulgencio Batista
       </a>
       , overthrew Cespedes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MJ303_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MJ303-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A five-member executive committee (the
       <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy_of_1933" title="Pentarchy of 1933">
        Pentarchy of 1933
       </a>
       ) was chosen to head a provisional government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Suchlicki2002_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Suchlicki2002-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_Grau_San_Mart%C3%ADn" title="Ramón Grau San Martín">
        Ramón Grau San Martín
       </a>
       was then appointed as provisional president.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Suchlicki2002_74-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Suchlicki2002-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Grau resigned in 1934, leaving the way clear for Batista, who dominated Cuban politics for the next 25 years, at first through a series of puppet-presidents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MJ303_73-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-MJ303-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The period from 1933 to 1937 was a time of "virtually unremitting social and political warfare".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1978_76_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1978_76-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On balance, during this period 1933–1940 Cuba is supported by a fragile politic reality that materialize in the decision making of three presidents in two years (1935–1936), as well as in the militaristic and repressive policies of Batista as
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Head_of_the_Army&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Head of the Army (page does not exist)">
        Head of the Army
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Constitution_of_1940">
        Constitution of 1940
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/1940_Constitution_of_Cuba" title="1940 Constitution of Cuba">
        new constitution
       </a>
       was adopted in 1940, which engineered radical progressive ideas, including the right to labour and health care.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1978_?_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1978_?-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Batista was elected president in the same year, holding the post until 1944.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villafana2011_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Villafana2011-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He is so far the only non-white Cuban to win the nation's highest political office.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horowitz_1988_662_78-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Horowitz_1988_662-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bethell_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bethell-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweig_2004_4_80-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sweig_2004_4-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His government carried out major social reforms. Several members of the Communist Party held office under his administration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweig_2004_?_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sweig_2004_?-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuban armed forces were not greatly involved in combat during World War II, although president Batista suggested a joint U.S.-Latin American assault on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_State" title="Spanish State">
        Francoist Spain
       </a>
       in order to overthrow its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">
        authoritarian
       </a>
       regime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Batista adhered to the 1940 constitution's strictures preventing his re-election.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1978_101_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1978_101-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ramon Grau San Martin was the winner of the next election, in 1944.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villafana2011_77-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Villafana2011-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Grau further corroded the base of the already teetering legitimacy of the Cuban political system, in particular by undermining the deeply flawed, though not entirely ineffectual, Congress and Supreme Court.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1978_110_111_84-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1978_110_111-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Pr%C3%ADo_Socarr%C3%A1s" title="Carlos Prío Socarrás">
        Carlos Prío Socarrás
       </a>
       , a protégé of Grau, became president in 1948.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villafana2011_77-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Villafana2011-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The two terms of the Auténtico Party saw an influx of investment which fueled a boom and raised living standards for all segments of society and created a prosperous middle class in most urban areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alvarez_2004_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Alvarez_2004-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HavanaSlums1954.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/HavanaSlums1954.jpg/210px-HavanaSlums1954.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/HavanaSlums1954.jpg/315px-HavanaSlums1954.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/HavanaSlums1954.jpg/420px-HavanaSlums1954.jpg 2x" width="210"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HavanaSlums1954.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Slum" title="Slum">
          Slum
         </a>
         (
         <i>
          bohio
         </i>
         ) dwellings in Havana, Cuba in 1954, just outside
         <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Latinoamericano" title="Estadio Latinoamericano">
          Havana baseball stadium
         </a>
         . In the background is advertising for a nearby
         <a href="/wiki/Casino" title="Casino">
          casino
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After finishing his term in 1944 Batista lived in Florida, returning to Cuba to run for president in 1952. Facing certain electoral defeat, he led a
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=1952_Cuban_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="1952 Cuban coup d'état (page does not exist)">
        military coup
       </a>
       that preempted the election.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Back in power, and receiving financial, military, and logistical support from the United States government,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Batista suspended the 1940 Constitution and revoked most political liberties, including the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right_to_strike" title="Right to strike">
        right to strike
       </a>
       . He then aligned with the wealthiest landowners who owned the largest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sugar_plantation" title="Sugar plantation">
        sugar plantations
       </a>
       , and presided over a stagnating economy that widened the gap between rich and poor Cubans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dictionary1950_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dictionary1950-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Batista outlawed the Cuban Communist Party in 1952.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweig_2004_6_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sweig_2004_6-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the coup, Cuba had Latin America's highest per capita consumption rates of meat, vegetables, cereals, automobiles, telephones and radios, though about one third of the population was considered poor and enjoyed relatively little of this consumption.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lewis_90-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lewis-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1958, Cuba was a relatively well-advanced country by Latin American standards, and in some cases by world standards.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asce_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-asce-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On the other hand, Cuba was affected by perhaps the largest labor union privileges in Latin America, including bans on dismissals and mechanization. They were obtained in large measure "at the cost of the unemployed and the peasants", leading to disparities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 1933 and 1958, Cuba extended economic regulations enormously, causing economic problems.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horowitz_1988_662_78-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Horowitz_1988_662-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thomas_1998_1173_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Thomas_1998_1173-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Unemployment became a problem as graduates entering the workforce could not find jobs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horowitz_1988_662_78-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Horowitz_1988_662-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The middle class, which was comparable to that of the United States, became increasingly dissatisfied with unemployment and political persecution. The labor unions supported Batista until the very end.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horowitz_1988_662_78-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Horowitz_1988_662-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bethell_79-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-bethell-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Batista stayed in power until he was forced into exile in December 1958.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IhrieOropesa2011_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-IhrieOropesa2011-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Revolution_and_Communist_party_rule_.281959.E2.80.93present.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Revolution_and_Communist_party_rule_(1959–present)">
        Revolution and Communist party rule (1959–present)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">
        Cuban Revolution
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CheyFidel.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1197" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/CheyFidel.jpg/170px-CheyFidel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/CheyFidel.jpg/255px-CheyFidel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/CheyFidel.jpg/340px-CheyFidel.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CheyFidel.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Che_Guevara" title="Che Guevara">
          Che Guevara
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">
          Fidel Castro
         </a>
         , photographed by
         <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Korda" title="Alberto Korda">
          Alberto Korda
         </a>
         in 1961
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the 1950s, various organizations, including some advocating armed uprising, competed for public support in bringing about political change.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chomsky2010_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chomsky2010-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1956,
       <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">
        Fidel Castro
       </a>
       and about 80 supporters landed from the yacht
       <a href="/wiki/Granma_(yacht)" title="Granma (yacht)">
        <i>
         Granma
        </i>
       </a>
       in an attempt to start a rebellion against the Batista government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chomsky2010_95-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chomsky2010-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was not until 1958 that Castro's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/July_26th_Movement" title="July 26th Movement">
        July 26th Movement
       </a>
       emerged as the leading revolutionary group.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chomsky2010_95-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chomsky2010-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By late 1958 the rebels had broken out of the Sierra Maestra and launched a general popular insurrection. After Castro's fighters captured
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Clara,_Cuba" title="Santa Clara, Cuba">
        Santa Clara
       </a>
       , Batista fled with his family to the Dominican Republic on 1 January 1959. Later he went into exile on the Portuguese island of Madeira and finally settled in Estoril, near Lisbon. Fidel Castro's forces entered the capital on 8 January 1959. The liberal
       <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Urrutia_Lle%C3%B3" title="Manuel Urrutia Lleó">
        Manuel Urrutia Lleó
       </a>
       became the provisional president.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falk_1988_67_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Falk_1988_67-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1959 to 1966 Cuban insurgents fought a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_against_the_Bandits" title="War against the Bandits">
        six-year rebellion
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Escambray_Mountains" title="Escambray Mountains">
        Escambray Mountains
       </a>
       against the Castro government. The government's vastly superior numbers eventually crushed the insurgency. The rebellion lasted longer and involved more soldiers than the Cuban Revolution.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ros_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ros-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cuba_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cuba-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The U.S. State Department has estimated that 3,200 people were executed from 1959 to 1962.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">
        Amnesty International
       </a>
       , death sentences from 1959–87 numbered 237 of which all but 21 were actually carried out.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other estimates for the total number of political executions range from 4,000 to 33,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Power_Kills_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Power_Kills-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The vast majority of those executed following the 1959 revolution were policemen, politicians, and informers of the Batista regime accused of crimes such as torture and murder, and their public trials and executions had widespread popular support among the Cuban population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chase_2010_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chase_2010-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1150" data-file-width="1606" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg/220px-Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg/330px-Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg/440px-Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
