         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Guantanamo_Naval_Base_aerial_photo_1962.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Since 1959, Cuba has regarded the U.S. presence in
         <a href="/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay_Naval_Base" title="Guantanamo Bay Naval Base">
          Guantánamo Bay
         </a>
         as illegal.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
          <a href="#cite_note-105">
           [105]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The United States government initially reacted favorably to the Cuban revolution, seeing it as part of a movement to bring democracy to Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rabe1988_106-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rabe1988-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Castro's legalization of the Communist party and the hundreds of executions that followed caused a deterioration in the relationship between the two countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rabe1988_106-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rabe1988-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The promulgation of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agrarian_Reform_Laws_of_Cuba" title="Agrarian Reform Laws of Cuba">
        Agrarian Reform Law
       </a>
       , expropriating thousands of acres of farmland (including from large U.S. landholders), further worsened relations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rabe1988_106-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rabe1988-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crooker2005_107-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Crooker2005-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response, between 1960 and 1964 the U.S imposed a range of sanctions, eventually including a total ban on trade between the countries and a freeze on all Cuban-owned assets in the U.S.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Commission_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Commission-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 1960, Castro signed a commercial agreement with Soviet Vice-Premier
       <a href="/wiki/Anastas_Mikoyan" title="Anastas Mikoyan">
        Anastas Mikoyan
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rabe1988_106-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rabe1988-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In March 1960, Eisenhower gave his approval to a CIA plan to arm and train a group of Cuban refugees to overthrow the Castro regime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The invasion (known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion" title="Bay of Pigs Invasion">
        Bay of Pigs Invasion
       </a>
       ) took place on 14 April 1961.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crooker2005_107-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Crooker2005-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 1,400 Cuban exiles disembarked at the
       <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs" title="Bay of Pigs">
        Bay of Pigs
       </a>
       , but failed in their attempt to overthrow Castro.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crooker2005_107-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Crooker2005-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In January 1962, Cuba was suspended from the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        Organization of American States
       </a>
       (OAS), and later the same year the OAS started to impose sanctions against Cuba of similar nature to the US sanctions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peterson_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peterson-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">
        Cuban Missile Crisis
       </a>
       occurred in October 1962. By 1963, Cuba was moving towards a full-fledged Communist system modeled on the USSR.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040,_Berlin,_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="776" data-file-width="800" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040%2C_Berlin%2C_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-L0614-040,_Berlin,_Fidel_Castro_an_der_Grenze.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Fidel Castro and members of the
         <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">
          East German
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Politburo" title="Politburo">
          Politburo
         </a>
         in 1972
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the 1970s, Fidel Castro dispatched tens of thousands of troops in support of Soviet-supported wars in Africa. He supported the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Popular_Movement_for_the_Liberation_of_Angola" title="Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola">
        MPLA
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">
        Angola
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Haile_Mariam" title="Mengistu Haile Mariam">
        Mengistu Haile Mariam
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">
        Ethiopia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1989_?_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1989_?-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The standard of living in the 1970s was "extremely spartan" and discontent was rife.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cambridge_113-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cambridge-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fidel Castro admitted the failures of economic policies in a 1970 speech.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cambridge_113-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cambridge-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1975 the OAS lifted its sanctions against Cuba, with the approval of 16 member states, including the U.S. The U.S., however, maintained its own sanctions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peterson_110-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peterson-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Castro's rule was severely tested in the aftermath of the Soviet collapse in 1991 (known in Cuba as the
       <a href="/wiki/Special_Period" title="Special Period">
        Special Period
       </a>
       ). The country faced a severe economic downturn following the withdrawal of Soviet subsidies worth
       <span class="nowrap">
        $4 billion
       </span>
       to
       <span class="nowrap">
        $6 billion
       </span>
       annually, resulting in effects such as food and fuel shortages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cmaj_114-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cmaj-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government did not accept American donations of food, medicines, and cash until 1993.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cmaj_114-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cmaj-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 5 August 1994, state security dispersed protesters in a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maleconazo_uprising" title="Maleconazo uprising">
        spontaneous protest
       </a>
       in Havana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FidelCastro645.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1181" data-file-width="1801" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/FidelCastro645.jpg/220px-FidelCastro645.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/FidelCastro645.jpg/330px-FidelCastro645.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/FidelCastro645.jpg/440px-FidelCastro645.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FidelCastro645.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Fidel Castro with South African president
         <a href="/wiki/Thabo_Mbeki" title="Thabo Mbeki">
          Thabo Mbeki
         </a>
         and the Swedish prime minister
         <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6ran_Persson" title="Göran Persson">
          Göran Persson
         </a>
         , 2005
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba has since found a new source of aid and support in the People's Republic of China. In addition,
       <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Hugo Chávez">
        Hugo Chávez
       </a>
       , former
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Venezuela" title="President of Venezuela">
        President of Venezuela
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Evo_Morales" title="Evo Morales">
        Evo Morales
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Bolivia" title="President of Bolivia">
        President of Bolivia
       </a>
       , became allies and both countries are major oil and gas exporters. In 2003, the government arrested and imprisoned a large number of civil activists, a period known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Spring_(Cuba)" title="Black Spring (Cuba)">
        "Black Spring"
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In February 2008, Fidel Castro announced his resignation as President of Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 24 February his brother,
       <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Raúl Castro">
        Raúl Castro
       </a>
       , was declared the new President.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In his inauguration speech, Raúl promised that some of the restrictions on freedom in Cuba would be removed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2009, Raúl Castro removed some of
       <a href="/wiki/2009_Cuban_government_dismissals" title="2009 Cuban government dismissals">
        his brother's appointees
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 3 June 2009, the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        Organization of American States
       </a>
       adopted a resolution to end the 47-year ban on Cuban membership of the group.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The resolution stated, however, that full membership would be delayed until Cuba was "in conformity with the practices, purposes, and principles of the OAS".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peterson_110-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peterson-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fidel Castro restated his position that he was not interested in joining after the OAS resolution had been announced.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="928" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png/220px-President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png/330px-President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png/440px-President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Obama_Meets_with_President_Castro.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Raúl Castro meets with U.S. President
         <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
          Barack Obama
         </a>
         in Panama, 11 April 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Effective 14 January 2013, Cuba ended the requirement established in 1961, that any citizens who wish to travel abroad were required to obtain an expensive government permit and a letter of invitation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1961 the Cuban government had imposed broad restrictions on travel to prevent the mass emigration of people after the 1959 revolution;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       it approved exit visas only on rare occasions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Requirements were simplified: Cubans need only a passport and a national ID card to leave; and they are allowed to take their young children with them for the first time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, a passport costs on average five months' salary. Observers expect that Cubans with paying relatives abroad are most likely to be able to take advantage of the new policy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the first year of the program, over 180,000 left Cuba and returned.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of December 2014, talks with Cuban officials and American officials including President Barack Obama have resulted in the exchange of releasing
       <a href="/wiki/Alan_Gross" title="Alan Gross">
        Alan Gross
       </a>
       , fifty-two political prisoners, and an unnamed non-citizen agent of the United States in return for the release of three Cuban agents currently imprisoned in the United States. Additionally, while the embargo between the United States and Cuba will not be immediately lifted, it will be relaxed to allow import, export, and certain commerce within a limit between the two.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">
        Government and politics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Cuba" title="Politics of Cuba">
        Politics of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CubaElectio.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CubaElectio.JPG/220px-CubaElectio.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CubaElectio.JPG/330px-CubaElectio.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CubaElectio.JPG/440px-CubaElectio.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CubaElectio.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Sign promoting the
         <a href="/wiki/Cuban_parliamentary_election,_2008" title="Cuban parliamentary election, 2008">
          2008 parliamentary election
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Republic of Cuba is one of the world's last remaining
       <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">
        socialist
       </a>
       countries following the
       <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">
        Marxist–Leninist
       </a>
       ideology. The Constitution of 1976, which defined Cuba as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_republic" title="Socialist republic">
        socialist republic
       </a>
       , was replaced by the Constitution of 1992, which is "guided by the ideas of
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mart%C3%AD" title="José Martí">
        José Martí
       </a>
       and the political and social ideas of
       <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">
        Marx
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Engels" title="Friedrich Engels">
        Engels
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">
        Lenin
       </a>
       ".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The constitution describes the
       <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Cuba" title="Communist Party of Cuba">
        Communist Party of Cuba
       </a>
       as the "leading force of society and of the state".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/First_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Cuba" title="First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba">
        First Secretary of the Communist Party
       </a>
       is concurrently President of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_State_of_Cuba" title="Council of State of Cuba">
        Council of State
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Cuba" title="President of Cuba">
        President of Cuba
       </a>
       ) and President of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Cuba" title="Council of Ministers of Cuba">
        Council of Ministers
       </a>
       (sometimes referred to as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Premier_of_Cuba" title="Premier of Cuba">
        Premier of Cuba
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Members of both councils are elected by the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_People%27s_Power" title="National Assembly of People's Power">
        National Assembly of People's Power
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The President of Cuba, who is also elected by the Assembly, serves for five years and there is no limit to the number of terms of office.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1584" data-file-width="3888" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg/220px-Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg/330px-Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg/440px-Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Comit%C3%A9_Central_PCC.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The headquarters of the
         <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Cuba" title="Communist Party of Cuba">
          Communist Party
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Supreme_Court_of_Cuba" title="People's Supreme Court of Cuba">
        People's Supreme Court
       </a>
       serves as Cuba's highest judicial branch of government. It is also the court of last resort for all appeals against the decisions of provincial courts.
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba's national legislature, the National Assembly of People's Power (
       <i>
        Asamblea Nacional de Poder Popular
       </i>
       ), is the supreme organ of power; 609 members serve five-year terms.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The assembly meets twice a year; between sessions legislative power is held by the 31 member Council of Ministers. Candidates for the Assembly are approved by public referendum. All Cuban citizens over 16 who have not been convicted of a criminal offense can vote.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Article 131 of the Constitution states that voting shall be "through free, equal and secret vote".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Article 136 states: "In order for deputies or delegates to be considered elected they must get more than half the number of valid votes cast in the electoral districts".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_4-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-constitution-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       No
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Cuba" title="List of political parties in Cuba">
        political party
       </a>
       is permitted to nominate candidates or campaign on the island, including the Communist Party.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Communist Party of Cuba has held six party congress meetings since 1975. In 2011, the party stated that there were 800,000 members, and representatives generally constitute at least half of the Councils of state and the National Assembly. The remaining positions are filled by candidates nominally without party affiliation. Other political parties campaign and raise finances internationally, while activity within Cuba by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Opposition_to_Fidel_Castro" title="Opposition to Fidel Castro">
        opposition groups
       </a>
       is minimal.
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba is considered an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">
        authoritarian
       </a>
       regime according to the 2016
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">
        Democracy Index
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-index2016_137-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-index2016-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 2017
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">
        Freedom in the World
       </a>
       survey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In February 2013, Raúl Castro, current Cuban President, announced his resignation for 2018, that will end his current 5-year term, and hopes to implement permanent term limits for future Cuban Presidents, including age limits.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After the death of Fidel Castro on 25 November 2016 the Cuban government put in place a nine-day mourning period. During the mourning period Cuban citizens were prohibited from playing loud music, partying, and drinking alcohol.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Cuba" title="Provinces of Cuba">
        Provinces of Cuba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Cuba" title="Municipalities of Cuba">
        Municipalities of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The country is subdivided into 15 provinces and one special municipality (Isla de la Juventud). These were formerly part of six larger historical provinces: Pinar del Río, Habana, Matanzas, Las Villas, Camagüey and Oriente. The present subdivisions closely resemble those of the Spanish military provinces during the Cuban Wars of Independence, when the most troublesome areas were subdivided. The provinces are divided into municipalities.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CubaSubdivisions.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="339" data-file-width="800" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/CubaSubdivisions.png/440px-CubaSubdivisions.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/CubaSubdivisions.png/660px-CubaSubdivisions.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/88/CubaSubdivisions.png 2x" width="440"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CubaSubdivisions.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Provinces of Cuba
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="background:transparent">
       <tr>
        <td style="padding-right:1em;">
         <ol>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Pinar_del_R%C3%ADo_Province" title="Pinar del Río Province">
            Pinar del Río
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Artemisa_Province" title="Artemisa Province">
            Artemisa
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">
            Havana
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Mayabeque_Province" title="Mayabeque Province">
            Mayabeque
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Matanzas_Province" title="Matanzas Province">
            Matanzas
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Cienfuegos_Province" title="Cienfuegos Province">
            Cienfuegos
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Villa_Clara_Province" title="Villa Clara Province">
            Villa Clara
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Sancti_Sp%C3%ADritus_Province" title="Sancti Spíritus Province">
            Sancti Spíritus
           </a>
          </li>
         </ol>
        </td>
        <td>
         <ol start="9">
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Ciego_de_%C3%81vila_Province" title="Ciego de Ávila Province">
            Ciego de Ávila
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Camag%C3%BCey_Province" title="Camagüey Province">
            Camagüey
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Las_Tunas_Province" title="Las Tunas Province">
            Las Tunas
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Granma_Province" title="Granma Province">
            Granma
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Holgu%C3%ADn_Province" title="Holguín Province">
            Holguín
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Cuba_Province" title="Santiago de Cuba Province">
            Santiago de Cuba
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Guant%C3%A1namo_Province" title="Guantánamo Province">
            Guantánamo
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_la_Juventud" title="Isla de la Juventud">
            Isla de la Juventud
           </a>
          </li>
         </ol>
        </td>
        <td>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">
        Human rights
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Cuba" title="Human rights in Cuba">
        Human rights in Cuba
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Cuba" title="Censorship in Cuba">
        Censorship in Cuba
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_dissidents" title="Cuban dissidents">
        Cuban dissidents
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana,_Cuba.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1787" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg/220px-Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg/330px-Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg/440px-Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana%2C_Cuba.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Damas_de_Blanco_demonstration_in_Havana,_Cuba.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ladies_in_White" title="Ladies in White">
          Ladies in White
         </a>
         demonstration in
         <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">
          Havana
         </a>
         (April 2012)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Cuban government has been accused of numerous
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_abuse" title="Human rights abuse">
        human rights abuses
       </a>
       including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Torture_in_Cuba" title="Torture in Cuba">
        torture
       </a>
       , arbitrary imprisonment, unfair trials, and extrajudicial executions (also known as "
       <i>
        El Paredón
       </i>
       ").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cidh_141-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cidh-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">
        Human Rights Watch
       </a>
       has stated that the government "represses nearly all forms of political dissent" and that "Cubans are systematically denied basic rights to free expression, association, assembly, privacy, movement, and due process of law".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw2006_143-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hrw2006-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2003, the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       (EU) accused the Cuban government of "continuing flagrant violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has continued to call regularly for social and economic reform in Cuba, along with the unconditional release of all
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_prisoners" title="Political prisoners">
        political prisoners
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laursen_145-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Laursen-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The United States continues an
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_embargo_against_Cuba" title="United States embargo against Cuba">
        embargo
       </a>
       against Cuba "so long as it continues to refuse to move toward democratization and greater respect for human rights",
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       though the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_General_Assembly" title="UN General Assembly">
        UN General Assembly
       </a>
       has, since 1992, passed a resolution every year condemning the ongoing impact of the embargo and claiming it to be in violation of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_United_Nations" title="Charter of the United Nations">
        Charter of the United Nations
       </a>
       and international law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba considers the embargo itself to be in violation of human rights.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 17 December 2014, United States President
       <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
        Barack Obama
       </a>
       announced the re-establishment of diplomatic relations with Cuba, pushing for Congress to put an end to the embargo.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba had the second-highest number of imprisoned journalists of any nation in 2008 (
       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
        China
       </a>
       had the highest) according to various sources, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">
        Committee to Protect Journalists
       </a>
       and Human Rights Watch.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_dissidents" title="Cuban dissidents">
        Cuban dissidents
       </a>
       face arrest and imprisonment. In the 1990s, Human Rights Watch reported that Cuba's extensive prison system, one of the largest in Latin America, consists of 40 maximum-security prisons, 30 minimum-security prisons, and over 200 work camps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw1999_152-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hrw1999-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to Human Rights Watch, Cuba's prison population is confined in "substandard and unhealthy conditions, where prisoners face physical and sexual abuse".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw1999_152-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-hrw1999-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In July 2010, the unofficial Cuban Human Rights Commission said there were 167 political prisoners in Cuba, a fall from 201 at the start of the year. The head of the commission stated that long prison sentences were being replaced by harassment and intimidation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the entire period of Castro's rule over the island, an estimated 200,000 people had been imprisoned or deprived of their freedoms for political reasons.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gonzalo-castro_17-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-gonzalo-castro-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Cuba" title="Foreign relations of Cuba">
        Foreign relations of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_medical_internationalism" title="Cuban medical internationalism">
        Cuban medical internationalism
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Havana11.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="904" data-file-width="1480" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Havana11.JPG/220px-Havana11.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Havana11.JPG/330px-Havana11.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Havana11.JPG/440px-Havana11.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Havana11.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Propaganda sign in front of the
         <a href="/wiki/United_States_Interests_Section_in_Havana" title="United States Interests Section in Havana">
          United States Interests Section in Havana
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba under Castro was heavily involved in wars in Africa, Central America and Asia.
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba supported
       <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">
        Algeria
       </a>
       in 1961–1965.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_1996_159,161_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_1996_159,161-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba sent tens of thousands of troops to
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_intervention_in_Angola" title="Cuban intervention in Angola">
        Angola
       </a>
       during the
       <a href="/wiki/Angolan_Civil_War" title="Angolan Civil War">
        Angolan Civil War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_2010_327_155-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_2010_327-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other countries that featured Cuban involvement include
       <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">
        Ethiopia
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_2002_392_156-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_2002_392-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tareke_2009_62to63_157-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tareke_2009_62to63-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Guinea" title="Guinea">
        Guinea
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_1997_50_158-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_1997_50-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Guinea-Bissau" title="Guinea-Bissau">
        Guinea-Bissau
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_1997_45_159-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_1997_45-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">
        Mozambique
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gleijeses_2002_227_160-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gleijeses_2002_227-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">
        Yemen
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamazani1975[https://books.google.com/books?id=7ETnbmUmxoUC&amp;pg=PA91_91]_161-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamazani1975[https://books.google.com/books?id=7ETnbmUmxoUC&amp;pg=PA91_91]-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba has conducted a foreign policy that is uncharacteristic of such a minor, developing country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_1989_6_162-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_1989_6-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feinsilver_1989_2_163-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Feinsilver_1989_2-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lesser known actions include the 1959 missions to the
       <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">
        Dominican Republic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The expedition failed, but a prominent monument to its members was erected in their memory in
       <a href="/wiki/Santo_Domingo" title="Santo Domingo">
        Santo Domingo
       </a>
       by the Dominican government, and they feature prominently at the country's Memorial Museum of the Resistance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba is a founding member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Alliance_for_the_Americas" title="Bolivarian Alliance for the Americas">
        Bolivarian Alliance for the Americas
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the end of 2012, tens of thousands of Cuban medical personnel worked abroad,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with as many as 30,000 doctors in Venezuela alone via the two countries' oil-for-doctors programme.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1996, the United States, then under President
       <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">
        Bill Clinton
       </a>
       , brought in the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act, better known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Helms%E2%80%93Burton_Act" title="Helms–Burton Act">
        Helms–Burton Act
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg/330px-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg/440px-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4_%D0%B2_%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_70-%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_-_42.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Raúl Castro with Mongolian President
         <a href="/wiki/Tsakhiagiin_Elbegdorj" title="Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj">
          Elbegdorj
         </a>
         during the
         <a href="/wiki/2015_Moscow_Victory_Day_Parade" title="2015 Moscow Victory Day Parade">
          Moscow Victory Day Parade
         </a>
         , 9 May 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2008, the EU and Cuba agreed to resume full relations and cooperation activities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       United States President
       <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
        Barack Obama
       </a>
       stated on April 17, 2009, in
       <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">
        Trinidad and Tobago
       </a>
       that "the United States seeks a new beginning with Cuba",
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and reversed the
       <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">
        Bush Administration
       </a>
       's prohibition on travel and remittances by Cuban-Americans from the United States to Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 17 December 2014, an agreement between the United States and Cuba, popularly called "The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_Thaw" title="Cuban Thaw">
        Cuban Thaw
       </a>
       ", brokered in part by
       <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
        Canada
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">
        Pope Francis
       </a>
       , began the process of restoring international relations between Cuba and the United States. Cuba and the US agreed to release political prisoners and the United States began the process of creating an embassy in Havana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 14 April 2015, the
       <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
        White House
       </a>
       announced President Obama will remove Cuba from the American government's list of nations which sponsor terrorism.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Cuban government has reportedly welcomed the decision as "fair".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 30 June 2015, Cuba and the U.S. reached a deal to reopen embassies in their respective capitals on 20 July 2015
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and reestablish diplomatic relations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 17 September 2017, the United States considered closing its Cuban embassy following mysterious sonic attacks on its staff.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Crime_and_law_enforcement">
        Crime and law enforcement
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Cuba" title="Law enforcement in Cuba">
        Law enforcement in Cuba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Cuba" title="Crime in Cuba">
        Crime in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuba_police_car_01.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3019" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Cuba_police_car_01.JPG/220px-Cuba_police_car_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Cuba_police_car_01.JPG/330px-Cuba_police_car_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Cuba_police_car_01.JPG/440px-Cuba_police_car_01.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cuba_police_car_01.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a href="/wiki/Lada_Riva" title="Lada Riva">
          Lada Riva
         </a>
         police car in
         <a href="/wiki/Holgu%C3%ADn" title="Holguín">
          Holguín
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       All law enforcement agencies are maintained under Cuba's Ministry of the Interior which is supervised by the
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolutionary_Armed_Forces" title="Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces">
        Revolutionary Armed Forces
       </a>
       . In Cuba, citizens can receive police assistance by dialing "106" on their
       <a href="/wiki/Telephone" title="Telephone">
        telephones
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The police force, which is referred to as "Policía Nacional Revolucionaria" or PNR is then expected to provide help. The Cuban government also has an agency called the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intelligence_Directorate" title="Intelligence Directorate">
        Intelligence Directorate
       </a>
       that conducts intelligence operations and maintains close ties with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Security_Service_(Russia)" title="Federal Security Service (Russia)">
        Russian Federal Security Service
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolutionary_Armed_Forces" title="Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces">
        Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       As of 2009
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cuba&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Cuba spent about
       <span class="nowrap">
        US$91.8 million
       </span>
       on its armed forces.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1985, Cuba devoted more than 10% of its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP">
        GDP
       </a>
       to military expenditures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response to perceived American aggression, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion" title="Bay of Pigs Invasion">
        Bay of Pigs Invasion
       </a>
       , Cuba built up one of the largest armed forces in Latin America, second only to that of
       <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Armed_Forces" title="Brazilian Armed Forces">
        Brazil
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-military_187-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-military-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1975 until the late 1980s,
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Armed_Forces" title="Soviet Armed Forces">
        Soviet military
       </a>
       assistance enabled Cuba to upgrade its military capabilities. After the loss of Soviet subsidies, Cuba scaled down the numbers of military personnel, from 235,000 in 1994 to about 60,000 in 2003.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Cuba" title="Economy of Cuba">
        Economy of Cuba
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rationing_in_Cuba" title="Rationing in Cuba">
        Rationing in Cuba
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sociolismo" title="Sociolismo">
        Sociolismo
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_embargo_against_Cuba" title="United States embargo against Cuba">
        United States embargo against Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="862" data-file-width="1104" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg/220px-Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg/330px-Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg/440px-Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_2009_Cuba.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cuban export composition, 2009
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Cuban state claims to adhere to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist" title="Socialist">
        socialist
       </a>
       principles in organizing its largely state-controlled
       <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">
        planned economy
       </a>
       . Most of the means of production are owned and run by the government and most of the labor force is employed by the state. Recent years have seen a trend toward more private sector employment. By 2006, public sector employment was 78% and private sector 22%, compared to 91.8% to 8.2% in 1981.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Government spending is 78.1% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Any firm wishing to hire a Cuban must pay the Cuban government, which in turn will pay the employee in Cuban pesos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The average monthly wage as of July 2013 is 466
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_pesos" title="Cuban pesos">
        Cuban pesos
       </a>
       , which are worth about US$19.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moneytalk_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-moneytalk-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Libreta_line_Havana.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Libreta_line_Havana.jpg/220px-Libreta_line_Havana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Libreta_line_Havana.jpg/330px-Libreta_line_Havana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Libreta_line_Havana.jpg/440px-Libreta_line_Havana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Libreta_line_Havana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         People waiting in line at a libreta store in Havana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba has a dual currency system, whereby most wages and prices are set in Cuban pesos (CUP), while the tourist economy operates with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convertible_peso" title="Convertible peso">
        Convertible pesos
       </a>
       (CUC), set at par with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_dollar" title="US dollar">
        US dollar
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moneytalk_192-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-moneytalk-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Every Cuban household has a ration book (known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libreta" title="Libreta">
        libreta
       </a>
       ) entitling it to a monthly supply of food and other staples, which are provided at nominal cost.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dealsoff_193-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-dealsoff-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Before Fidel Castro's 1959 revolution, Cuba was one of the most advanced and successful countries in Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pbs.org_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pbs.org-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba's capital, Havana, was a "glittering and dynamic city".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pbs.org_194-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-pbs.org-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country's economy in the early part of the century, fuelled by the sale of sugar to the United States, had grown wealthy. Cuba ranked 5th in the hemisphere in per capita income, 3rd in life expectancy, 2nd in per capita ownership of automobiles and telephones, and 1st in the number of television sets per inhabitant. Cuba's literacy rate, 76%, was the fourth highest in Latin America. Cuba also ranked 11th in the world in the number of doctors per capita. Several private clinics and hospitals provided services for the poor. Cuba's income distribution compared favorably with that of other Latin American societies. However, income inequality was profound between city and countryside, especially between whites and blacks. Cubans lived in abysmal poverty in the countryside. According to PBS, a thriving middle class held the promise of prosperity and social mobility.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pbs.org_194-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-pbs.org-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to Cuba historian Louis Perez of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, "Havana was then what Las Vegas has become."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, the Miami Herald wrote, "... about 27 percent of Cubans earn under $50 per month; 34 percent earn the equivalent of $50 to $100 per month; and 20 percent earn $101 to $200. Twelve percent reported earning $201 to $500 a month; and almost 4 percent said their monthly earnings topped $500, including 1.5 percent who said they earned more than $1,000."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SantiagoPeople_01.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1712" data-file-width="2288" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/SantiagoPeople_01.JPG/220px-SantiagoPeople_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/SantiagoPeople_01.JPG/330px-SantiagoPeople_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/SantiagoPeople_01.JPG/440px-SantiagoPeople_01.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SantiagoPeople_01.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cigar production in
         <a href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Cuba" title="Santiago de Cuba">
          Santiago de Cuba
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the Cuban revolution and before the collapse of the Soviet Union, Cuba depended on Moscow for substantial aid and sheltered markets for its exports. The loss of these subsidies sent the Cuban economy into a rapid depression known in Cuba as the
       <a href="/wiki/Special_Period" title="Special Period">
        Special Period
       </a>
       . Cuba took limited free market-oriented measures to alleviate severe shortages of food, consumer goods, and services. These steps included allowing some self-employment in certain retail and light manufacturing sectors, the legalization of the use of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_dollar" title="US dollar">
        US dollar
       </a>
       in business, and the encouragement of
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Cuba" title="Tourism in Cuba">
        tourism
       </a>
       . Cuba has developed a unique urban farm system called
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Organop%C3%B3nicos" title="Organopónicos">
         organopónicos
        </a>
       </i>
       to compensate for the end of food imports from the Soviet Union. The
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_embargo_against_Cuba" title="United States embargo against Cuba">
        U.S. embargo
       </a>
       against Cuba was instituted in response to nationalization of U.S.-citizen-held property and was maintained at the premise of perceived human rights violations. It is widely viewed that the embargo hurt the Cuban economy. In 2009, the Cuban Government estimated this loss at $685 million annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dollarsandsense.org_197-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-dollarsandsense.org-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba's leadership has called for reforms in the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Cuba" title="Agriculture in Cuba">
        agricultural system
       </a>
       . In 2008, Raúl Castro began enacting agrarian reforms to boost food production, as at that time 80% of food was imported. The reforms aim to expand land use and increase efficiency.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-food_198-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-food-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Venezuela supplies Cuba with an estimated 110,000 barrels (17,000 m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) of oil per day in exchange for money and the services of some 44,000 Cubans, most of them medical personnel, in Venezuela.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VenezuelaReuters_199-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VenezuelaReuters-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VenezuelaAES_200-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VenezuelaAES-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2797" data-file-width="4192" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg/220px-Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg/330px-Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg/440px-Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Havana_-_Cuba_-_2756.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cubans are now permitted to own small businesses in certain sectors.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2005, Cuba had exports of
       <span class="nowrap">
        US$2.4 billion
       </span>
       , ranking 114 of 226 world countries, and imports of
       <span class="nowrap">
        US$6.9 billion
       </span>
       , ranking 87 of 226 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its major export partners are Canada 17.7%, China 16.9%,
       <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       12.5%,
       <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
        Netherlands
       </a>
       9%, and Spain 5.9% (2012).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_202-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba's major exports are sugar, nickel, tobacco, fish, medical products, citrus fruits, and coffee;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_202-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       imports include food, fuel, clothing, and machinery. Cuba presently holds debt in an amount estimated to be
       <span class="nowrap">
        $13 billion
       </span>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       approximately 38% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heritage_Foundation" title="Heritage Foundation">
        Heritage Foundation
       </a>
       , Cuba is dependent on credit accounts that rotate from country to country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-catholic_205-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-catholic-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba's prior 35% supply of the world's export market for sugar has declined to 10% due to a variety of factors, including a global sugar commodity price drop that made Cuba less competitive on world markets.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was announced in 2008 that wage caps would be abandoned to improve the nation's productivity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2010
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cuba&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Cubans were allowed to build their own houses. According to Raúl Castro, they could now improve their houses, but the government would not endorse these new houses or improvements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There is virtually no homelessness in Cuba, and 85% of Cubans own their homes and pay no property taxes or mortgage interest. Mortgage payments may not exceed 10% of a household's combined income.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dollarsandsense.org_197-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-dollarsandsense.org-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 2 August 2011,
       <i>
        The New York Times
       </i>
       reported that Cuba reaffirmed its intent to legalize "buying and selling" of private property before the year's end. According to experts, the private sale of property could "transform Cuba more than any of the economic reforms announced by President Raúl Castro's government".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It would cut more than one million state jobs, including party bureaucrats who resist the changes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The reforms created what some call "New Cuban Economy".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In October 2013, Raúl said he intended to merge the two currencies, but as of August 2016, the dual currency system remains in force.
      </p>
      <p>
       In August 2012, a specialist of the "Cubaenergia Company" announced the opening of Cuba's first Solar Power Plant. As a member of the Cubasolar Group, there was also a mention of 10 additional plants in 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Resources">
        Resources
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Cuba's natural resources include sugar, tobacco, fish, citrus fruits,
       <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Cuba" title="Coffee production in Cuba">
        coffee
       </a>
       , beans, rice, potatoes, and livestock.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The output of Cuba's nickel mines that year was 71,000 tons, approaching 4% of world production.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_216-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-USGS-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2013
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cuba&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       its reserves were estimated at 5.5 million tons, over 7% of the world total.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_216-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-USGS-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Sherritt_International" title="Sherritt International">
        Sherritt International
       </a>
       of Canada operates a large nickel mining facility in
       <a href="/wiki/Moa,_Cuba" title="Moa, Cuba">
        Moa
       </a>
       . Cuba is also a major producer of refined
       <a href="/wiki/Cobalt" title="Cobalt">
        cobalt
       </a>
       , a by-product of nickel mining.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-torres_217-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-torres-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Oil exploration in 2005 by the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey" title="United States Geological Survey">
        US Geological Survey
       </a>
       revealed that the North Cuba Basin could produce about 4.6 billion barrels (730,000,000 m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) to 9.3 billion barrels (1.48
       <span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">
        ×
       </span>
       10
       <sup>
        9
       </sup>
       m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) of oil. In 2006, Cuba started to test-drill these locations for possible exploitation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Cuba" title="Tourism in Cuba">
        Tourism in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Varaderos_beach_(5982433102).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3239" data-file-width="4891" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg/220px-Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg/330px-Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg/440px-Varaderos_beach_%285982433102%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Varaderos_beach_(5982433102).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Varadero" title="Varadero">
          Varadero
         </a>
         beach
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Tourism was initially restricted to enclave resorts where tourists would be segregated from Cuban society, referred to as "enclave tourism" and "tourism apartheid".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Contact between foreign visitors and ordinary Cubans were
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       illegal between 1992 and 1997.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Corbett_2002_33_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Corbett_2002_33-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The rapid growth of tourism during the Special Period had widespread social and economic repercussions in Cuba, and led to speculation about the emergence of a two-tier economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba has tripled its market share of Caribbean tourism in the last decade;
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
          <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (July 2013)">
           when?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       as a result of significant investment in tourism infrastructure, this growth rate is predicted to continue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <span class="nowrap">
        1.9 million
       </span>
       tourists visited Cuba in 2003, predominantly from Canada and the European Union, generating revenue of
       <span class="nowrap">
        US$2.1 billion
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba recorded 2,688,000 international tourists in 2011, the third-highest figure in the Caribbean (behind the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unwto_224-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-unwto-224">
         [224]
        </a>
