       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">
        medical tourism
       </a>
       sector caters to thousands of European, Latin American, Canadian, and American consumers every year.
      </p>
      <p>
       Allegations of widespread
       <a href="/wiki/Sex_tourism" title="Sex tourism">
        sex tourism
       </a>
       are downplayed by the Cuban Justice minister.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Justice_Minister_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Justice_Minister-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a Government of Canada travel advice website, "Cuba is actively working to prevent child sex tourism, and a number of tourists, including Canadians, have been convicted of offences related to the corruption of minors aged 16 and under. Prison sentences range from 7 to 25 years."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some tourist facilities were extensively damaged on 8 September 2017 when
       <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">
        Hurricane Irma
       </a>
       hit the island. The storm made landfall in the Camagüey Archipelago; the worst damage was in the keys north of the main island, however, and not in the most significant tourist areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_227-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Cuba" title="Geography of Cuba">
        Geography of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuba_rel94.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="977" data-file-width="1415" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Cuba_rel94.jpg/220px-Cuba_rel94.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Cuba_rel94.jpg/330px-Cuba_rel94.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Cuba_rel94.jpg/440px-Cuba_rel94.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cuba_rel94.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A general map of Cuba
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba is an
       <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">
        archipelago
       </a>
       of islands located in the northern
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">
        Caribbean Sea
       </a>
       at the confluence with the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">
        Gulf of Mexico
       </a>
       and the Atlantic Ocean. It lies between latitudes
       <a href="/wiki/19th_parallel_north" title="19th parallel north">
        19°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/24th_parallel_north" title="24th parallel north">
        24°N
       </a>
       , and longitudes
       <a href="/wiki/74th_meridian_west" title="74th meridian west">
        74°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/85th_meridian_west" title="85th meridian west">
        85°W
       </a>
       . The United States lies 150 kilometers (93 miles) across the
       <a href="/wiki/Straits_of_Florida" title="Straits of Florida">
        Straits of Florida
       </a>
       to the north and northwest (to the closest tip of
       <a href="/wiki/Key_West,_Florida" title="Key West, Florida">
        Key West, Florida
       </a>
       ), and
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bahamas" title="The Bahamas">
        the Bahamas
       </a>
       21 km (13 mi) to the north.
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       lies 210 kilometers (130 miles) across the
       <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n_Channel" title="Yucatán Channel">
        Yucatán Channel
       </a>
       to the west (to the closest tip of
       <a href="/wiki/Cabo_Catoche" title="Cabo Catoche">
        Cabo Catoche
       </a>
       in the State of
       <a href="/wiki/Quintana_Roo" title="Quintana Roo">
        Quintana Roo
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">
        Haiti
       </a>
       is 77 km (48 mi) to the east,
       <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">
        Jamaica
       </a>
       (140 km/87 mi) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">
        Cayman Islands
       </a>
       to the south. Cuba is the principal island, surrounded by four smaller groups of islands: the
       <a href="/wiki/Colorados_Archipelago" title="Colorados Archipelago">
        Colorados Archipelago
       </a>
       on the northwestern coast, the
       <a href="/wiki/Sabana-Camag%C3%BCey_Archipelago" title="Sabana-Camagüey Archipelago">
        Sabana-Camagüey Archipelago
       </a>
       on the north-central Atlantic coast, the
       <a href="/wiki/Jardines_de_la_Reina" title="Jardines de la Reina">
        Jardines de la Reina
       </a>
       on the south-central coast and the
       <a href="/wiki/Canarreos_Archipelago" title="Canarreos Archipelago">
        Canarreos Archipelago
       </a>
       on the southwestern coast.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2300" data-file-width="6029" height="84" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg/220px-Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg/330px-Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg/440px-Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sierra_Maestra_panorama1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Maestra" title="Sierra Maestra">
          Sierra Maestra
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The main island, named Cuba, is 1,250 km (780 mi) long, constituting most of the nation's land area (104,556 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (40,369 sq mi)) and is the largest island in the
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_by_area" title="List of islands by area">
        17th-largest island
       </a>
       in the world by land area. The main island consists mostly of flat to rolling plains apart from the
       <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Maestra" title="Sierra Maestra">
        Sierra Maestra
       </a>
       mountains in the southeast, whose highest point is
       <a href="/wiki/Pico_Turquino" title="Pico Turquino">
        Pico Turquino
       </a>
       (1,974 m (6,476 ft)).
      </p>
      <p>
       The second-largest island is
       <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_la_Juventud" title="Isla de la Juventud">
        Isla de la Juventud
       </a>
       (Isle of Youth) in the Canarreos archipelago, with an area of 2,200 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (849 sq mi). Cuba has an official area (land area) of 109,884 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (42,426 sq mi). Its area is 110,860 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (42,803 sq mi) including coastal and territorial waters.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Climate_of_Cuba" title="Climate of Cuba">
        Climate of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Valle_vinales_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2304" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Valle_vinales_1.jpg/220px-Valle_vinales_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Valle_vinales_1.jpg/330px-Valle_vinales_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Valle_vinales_1.jpg/440px-Valle_vinales_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Valle_vinales_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Vi%C3%B1ales_Valley" title="Viñales Valley">
          Viñales Valley
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With the entire island south of the
       <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">
        Tropic of Cancer
       </a>
       , the local climate is tropical, moderated by northeasterly trade winds that blow year-round. The temperature is also shaped by the Caribbean current, which brings in warm water from the equator. This makes the climate of Cuba warmer than that of
       <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">
        Hong Kong
       </a>
       , which is at around the same latitude as Cuba but has a subtropical rather than a tropical climate. In general (with local variations), there is a drier season from November to April, and a rainier season from May to October. The average temperature is 21 °C (69.8 °F) in January and 27 °C (80.6 °F) in July. The warm temperatures of the Caribbean Sea and the fact that Cuba sits across the entrance to the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">
        Gulf of Mexico
       </a>
       combine to make the country prone to frequent
       <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">
        hurricanes
       </a>
       . These are most common in September and October.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">
        Hurricane Irma
       </a>
       hit the island on 8 September 2017, with winds of 260 kilometres per hour,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       at the Camagüey Archipelago; the storm reached Ciego de Avila province around midnight and continued to pound Cuba the next day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The worst damage was in the keys north of the main island. Hospitals, warehouses and factories were damaged; much of the north coast was without electricity. By that time, nearly a million people, including tourists, had been evacuated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_227-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Varadero resort area also reported widespread damage; the government believed that repairs could be completed before the start of the main tourist season.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn.com_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cnn.com-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Subsequent reports indicated that 10 people had been killed during the storm, including seven in Havana, most during building collapses. Sections of the capital had been flooded.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn.com_230-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cnn.com-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Jose_(2017)" title="Hurricane Jose (2017)">
        Hurricane Jose
       </a>
       was not expected to strike Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
        Biodiversity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Cuba signed the Rio
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">
        Convention on Biological Diversity
       </a>
       on 12 June 1992, and became a party to the convention on 8 March 1994.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has subsequently produced a
       <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">
        National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan
       </a>
       , with one revision which was received by the convention on 24 January 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The revision comprises an action plan with time limits for each item, and an indication of the governmental body responsible for delivery. That document contains virtually no information about biodiversity. However, the country's fourth national report to the
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">
        CBD
       </a>
       contains a detailed breakdown of the numbers of species of each kingdom of life recorded from Cuba, the main groups being:
       <a href="/wiki/Animal" title="Animal">
        animals
       </a>
       (17,801 species),
       <a href="/wiki/Bacteria" title="Bacteria">
        bacteria
       </a>
       (270),
       <a href="/wiki/Chromista" title="Chromista">
        chromista
       </a>
       (707),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fungi" title="Fungi">
        fungi
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Lichen" title="Lichen">
        lichen
       </a>
       -forming species (5844),
       <a href="/wiki/Plant" title="Plant">
        plants
       </a>
       (9107) and
       <a href="/wiki/Protozoa" title="Protozoa">
        protozoa
       </a>
       (1440).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As elsewhere in the world, vertebrate animals and flowering plants are well documented, so the recorded numbers of species are probably close to the true numbers. For most or all other groups, the true numbers of species occurring in Cuba are likely to exceed, often considerably, the numbers recorded so far.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_people" title="Cuban people">
        Cuban people
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Cuba" title="Demographics of Cuba">
        Demographics of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
        <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:none">
          <th colspan="5">
           Self-identified race (2012 Census)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-official_2012_Census_3-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-official_2012_Census-3">
             [3]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px;">
           Race
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">
            White
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:Blue; width:64.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           64.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">
            Mulatto
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">
            Mestizo
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Zambo" title="Zambo">
            Zambo
           </a>
           , or
           <a href="/wiki/Pardo" title="Pardo">
            Pardo
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:Green; width:27.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           27.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro_Cuban" title="Afro Cuban">
            Black
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:Red; width:9.3%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           9.3%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">
            Asian
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:Black; width:0.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Escuela_Lenin(estudiantes).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG/220px-Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG/330px-Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG/440px-Escuela_Lenin%28estudiantes%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Escuela_Lenin(estudiantes).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Students of the Escuela Lenin
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the official census of 2010, Cuba's population was 11,241,161, comprising 5,628,996 men and 5,612,165 women.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cubacensus2010_235-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cubacensus2010-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its
       <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">
        birth rate
       </a>
       (9.88 births per thousand population in 2006)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is one of the lowest in the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">
        Western Hemisphere
       </a>
       . Although the country's population has grown by about four million people since 1961, the rate of growth slowed during that period, and the population began to decline in 2006, due in the country's low
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" title="Fertility rate">
        fertility rate
       </a>
       (1.43 children per woman) coupled with emigration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Indeed, this drop in fertility is among the largest in the Western Hemisphere,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
        <a href="#cite_note-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is attributed largely to unrestricted access to legal abortion: Cuba's abortion rate was 58.6 per 1000 pregnancies in 1996, compared to an average of 35 in the Caribbean, 27 in Latin America overall, and 48 in Europe. Similarly, the use of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Contraception" title="Contraception">
        contraceptives
       </a>
       is also widespread, estimated at 79% of the female population (in the upper third of countries in the Western Hemisphere).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnoracial_groups">
        Ethnoracial groups
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Cuba's population is multiethnic, reflecting its complex colonial origins. Intermarriage between diverse groups is widespread, and consequently there is some discrepancy in reports of the country's racial composition: whereas the Institute for Cuban and Cuban-American Studies at the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Miami" title="University of Miami">
        University of Miami
       </a>
       determined that 62% of Cubans are black,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the 2002 Cuban census found that a similar proportion of the population, 65.05%, was white.
      </p>
      <p>
       In fact, the
       <a href="/wiki/Minority_Rights_Group_International" title="Minority Rights Group International">
        Minority Rights Group International
       </a>
       determined that "An objective assessment of the situation of
       <a href="/wiki/Afro-Cuban" title="Afro-Cuban">
        Afro-Cubans
       </a>
       remains problematic due to scant records and a paucity of systematic studies both pre- and post-revolution. Estimates of the percentage of people of African descent in the Cuban population vary enormously, ranging from 34% to 62%".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A study from 2014 found the
       <a href="/wiki/Autosome" title="Autosome">
        autosomal
       </a>
       genetic ancestry in Cuba to be 72% European, 20% African and 8% Native American;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plosgenetics.org_242-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-plosgenetics.org-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       35% of maternal lineages derived from Cuban Native Americans, compared to 39% from Africa and 26% from Europe, but male lineages were European (82%) and African (18%), indicating the historical bias towards mating between foreign men and native women rather than the inverse.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plosgenetics.org_242-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-plosgenetics.org-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed-hover" style="text-align:left">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 256px">
        <div style="width: 256px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 254px;">
          <div style="margin:-0.16666666666667px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1996" data-file-width="2900" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png/381px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png/573px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png/763px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_autosomal_AIMs.png 2x" width="254"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 234px">
          <div class="gallerytext">

            Ancestral contributions in Cubans as inferred from autosomal AIMs.
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>

            <img alt="" data-file-height="2052" data-file-width="2864" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png/366px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png/550px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png/733px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_Y-chromosome_markers.png 2x" width="244"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 224px">
          <div class="gallerytext">
           <p>
            Ancestral contributions in Cubans as inferred from Y-chromosome markers.
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 254px">
        <div style="width: 254px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 252px;">
          <div style="margin:-0.16666666666667px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2028" data-file-width="2921" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png/378px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png/568px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png/756px-Distribution_of_ancestral_contributions_in_Cuba_as_inferred_from_mtDNA_markers.png 2x" width="252"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 232px">
          <div class="gallerytext">
           <p>
            Ancestral contributions in Cubans as inferred from mtDNA markers.
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">
        Asians
       </a>
       make up about 1% of the population, and are largely of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Cuban" title="Chinese Cuban">
        Chinese ancestry
       </a>
       , followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">
        Filipinos
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">
        Japanese
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_people" title="Vietnamese people">
        Vietnamese
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Many are descendants of farm laborers brought to the island by Spanish and American contractors during the 19th and early 20th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
        <a href="#cite_note-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The currently recorded number of Cubans with Chinese ancestry is 114,240.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Cubans" title="Afro-Cubans">
        Afro-Cubans
       </a>
       are descended primarily from the
       <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_people" title="Yoruba people">
        Yoruba people
       </a>
       , Bantu people from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congo_basin" title="Congo basin">
        Congo basin
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carabali" title="Carabali">
        Carabali people
       </a>
       and Arará from the
       <a href="/wiki/Dahomey" title="Dahomey">
        Dahomey
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as several thousand
       <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">
        North African
       </a>
       refugees, most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Sahrawi_people" title="Sahrawi people">
        Sahrawi Arabs
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">
        Western Sahara
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration_and_emigration">
        Immigration and emigration
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_immigration_to_Cuba" title="Spanish immigration to Cuba">
        Spanish immigration to Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Immigration and emigration have played a prominent part in Cuba's demographic profile. Between the 18th and early 20th century, large waves of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canarian_people" title="Canarian people">
        Canarian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Catalans" title="Catalans">
        Catalan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Andalusians" title="Andalusians">
        Andalusian
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galician_people" title="Galician people">
        Galician
       </a>
       , and other Spanish people immigrated to Cuba. Between 1899–1930 alone, close to a million Spaniards entered the country, though many would eventually return to Spain.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other prominent immigrant groups included French,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_people" title="Italian people">
        Italian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">
        Russian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">
        Dutch
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
        Greek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">
        British
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">
        Irish
       </a>
       , as well as small number of descendants of U.S. citizens who arrived in Cuba in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
      </p>
      <p>
       Post-revolution Cuba has been characterized by significant levels of emigration, which has led to a
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_exile" title="Cuban exile">
        large and influential diaspora community
       </a>
       . During the three decades after January 1959, more than one million Cubans of all social classes — constituting 10% of the total population —
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_migration_to_Miami" title="Cuban migration to Miami">
        emigrated to the United States
       </a>
       , a proportion that matches the extent of emigration to the U.S. from the Caribbean as a whole during that period.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
        <a href="#cite_note-251">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedraza_2007_?_252-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedraza_2007_?-252">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falk_1988_74_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Falk_1988_74-253">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
        <a href="#cite_note-254">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedraza_2007_5_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedraza_2007_5-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other common destinations include Spain,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cubans_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cubans in the United Kingdom">
        the United Kingdom
       </a>
       , Canada,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Cuban immigration to Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       , and Sweden, among others. Those who left the country typically did so by sea, in small boats and fragile rafts. On 9 September 1994, the U.S. and Cuban governments agreed that the U.S. would grant at least 20,000 visas annually in exchange for Cuba's pledge to prevent further unlawful departures on boats.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Cuba" title="Religion in Cuba">
        Religion in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG/220px-2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG/330px-2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG/440px-2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2012-Catedral_de_San_Cristobal_anagoria_01.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Havana_Cathedral" title="Havana Cathedral">
          Havana Cathedral
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2010, the religious affiliation of the country was estimated by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Forum" title="Pew Forum">
        Pew Forum
       </a>
       to be 65% Christian (60%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">
        Roman Catholic
       </a>
       or about 6.9 million in 2016, 5%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
        Protestant
       </a>
       or about 575,000 in 2016), 23% unaffiliated, 17%
       <a href="/wiki/Folk_religion" title="Folk religion">
        folk religion
       </a>
       (such as
       <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">
        santería
       </a>
       ), and the remaining 0.4% consisting of other religions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewrel_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pewrel-257">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba is officially a secular state. Religious freedom increased through the 1980s,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the government amending the constitution in 1992 to drop the state's characterization as atheistic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Domínguez_2003_4_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Domínguez_2003_4-259">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">
        Roman Catholicism
       </a>
       is the largest religion, with its origins in Spanish colonization. Despite less than half of the population identifying as Catholics in 2006, it nonetheless remains the dominant faith.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-catholic_205-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-catholic-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Pope John Paul II and Pope Benedict XVI visited Cuba in 1998 and 2011, respectively, and Pope Francis visited Cuba in September 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
        <a href="#cite_note-261">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prior to each papal visit, the Cuban government pardoned prisoners as a humanitarian gesture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The government's relaxation of restrictions on
       <a href="/wiki/House_church" title="House church">
        house churches
       </a>
       in the 1990s led to an explosion of
       <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">
        Pentecostalism
       </a>
       , with some groups claiming as many as 100,000 members. However,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Protestant" title="Evangelical Protestant">
        Evangelical Protestant
       </a>
       denominations, organized into the umbrella Cuban Council of Churches, remain much more vibrant and powerful.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edmonds_264-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Edmonds-264">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The religious landscape of Cuba is also strongly defined by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syncretisms" title="Syncretisms">
        syncretisms
       </a>
       of various kinds. Christianity is often practiced in tandem with
       <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">
        Santería
       </a>
       , a mixture of Catholicism and mostly African faiths, which include a number of cults. La Virgen de la Caridad del Cobre (the Virgin of
       <i>
        Cobre
       </i>
       ) is the Catholic patroness of Cuba, and a symbol of Cuban culture. In Santería, she has been syncretized with the goddess
       <a href="/wiki/Oshun" title="Oshun">
        Oshun
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Cuba also hosts small communities of
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       (500 in 2012),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">
        Muslims
       </a>
       , and members of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD" title="Bahá'í">
        Bahá'í
       </a>
       Faith.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Several well-known Cuban religious figures have operated outside the island, including the humanitarian and author
       <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Armando_P%C3%A9rez" title="Jorge Armando Pérez">
        Jorge Armando Pérez
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The official language of Cuba is
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       and the vast majority of Cubans speak it. Spanish as spoken in Cuba is known as
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Spanish" title="Cuban Spanish">
        Cuban Spanish
       </a>
       and is a form of
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Spanish" title="Caribbean Spanish">
        Caribbean Spanish
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Lucum%C3%AD_language" title="Lucumí language">
        Lucumí
       </a>
       , a dialect of the West African language
       <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_language" title="Yoruba language">
        Yoruba
       </a>
       , is also used as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liturgical_language" title="Liturgical language">
        liturgical language
       </a>
       by practitioners of
       <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">
        Santería
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and so only as a second language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Creole" title="Haitian Creole">
        Haitian Creole
       </a>
       is the second most spoken language in Cuba, and is spoken by
       <a href="/wiki/Haitians" title="Haitians">
        Haitian
       </a>
       immigrants and their descendants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other languages spoken by immigrants include
       <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
        Galician
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Corsican_language" title="Corsican language">
        Corsican
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities">
        Largest cities
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Cuba" title="List of cities in Cuba">
        List of cities in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>

           </li>

             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>

           </a>
          </span>
         </div>

       </tr>

         </a>
         <br/>

        </td>
       </tr>

        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Holgu%C3%ADn" title="Holguín">

         </a>

         <a href="/wiki/Holgu%C3%ADn_Province" title="Holguín Province">

         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         269,618
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         5
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Santa_Clara,_Cuba" title="Santa Clara, Cuba">
          Santa Clara
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Villa_Clara_Province" title="Villa Clara Province">
          Villa Clara
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         210,220
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
