      </table>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Cuba" title="Media of Cuba">
        Media of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Cuban government and Communist Party of Cuba control almost all media in Cuba.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Press">
        Press
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Cuba" title="List of newspapers in Cuba">
        List of newspapers in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Granma_(newspaper)" title="Granma (newspaper)">
          Granma
         </a>
        </i>
        brings:
       </li>
      </ul>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <dl>
         <dd>
          <dl>
           <dd>
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.granma.cu/idiomas/ingles/reflections-i/reflections-i.html" rel="nofollow">
             Reflections of Fidel Castro
            </a>
           </dd>
           <dd>
            Speeches of Raúl Castro
           </dd>
          </dl>
         </dd>
        </dl>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Television">
        Television
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Cuba" title="Television in Cuba">
        Television in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Five Communist controlled national channels:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Cubavisi%C3%B3n" title="Cubavisión">
         Cubavisión
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Tele_Rebelde" title="Tele Rebelde">
         Tele Rebelde
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Canal_Educativo" title="Canal Educativo">
         Canal Educativo
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canal_Educativo_2" title="Canal Educativo 2">
         Canal Educativo 2
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Multivisi%C3%B3n_(Cuba)" title="Multivisión (Cuba)">
         Multivisión
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Internet">
        Internet
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_Cuba" title="Internet in Cuba">
        Internet in Cuba
       </a>
       has some of the lowest penetration rates in the Western hemisphere, and all content is subject to review by the
       <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Revolutionary_Orientation" title="Department of Revolutionary Orientation">
        Department of Revolutionary Orientation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bedroses_270-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bedroses-270">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/ETECSA" title="ETECSA">
        ETECSA
       </a>
       operates 118 cybercafes in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bedroses_270-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-bedroses-270">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government of Cuba provides an online encyclopedia website called
       <a href="/wiki/EcuRed" title="EcuRed">
        EcuRed
       </a>
       that operates in a "
       <a href="/wiki/Wiki" title="Wiki">
        wiki
       </a>
       " format.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
        <a href="#cite_note-271">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Internet access is limited.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
        <a href="#cite_note-272">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The sale of computer equipment is strictly regulated. Internet access is controlled, and e-mail is closely monitored.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rsf_273-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-rsf-273">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Cuba" title="Culture of Cuba">
        Culture of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg/220px-Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg/330px-Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg/440px-Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Casa_de_la_Trova_Santiago_Cuba.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A local musical house, Casa de la Trova in Santiago de Cuba
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuban culture is influenced by its melting pot of cultures, primarily those of Spain and Africa. After the 1959 revolution, the government started a national literacy campaign, offered free education to all and established rigorous sports, ballet and music programs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hsas_274-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hsas-274">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:208px;max-width:208px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="465" data-file-width="333" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg/100px-Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg/150px-Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg/200px-Gloria_Estefan_2009.jpg 2x" width="100"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Celia_Cruz_1.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Celia_Cruz_1.jpg/100px-Celia_Cruz_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Celia_Cruz_1.jpg/150px-Celia_Cruz_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Celia_Cruz_1.jpg/200px-Celia_Cruz_1.jpg 2x" width="100"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Estefan" title="Gloria Estefan">
          Gloria Estefan
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Celia_Cruz" title="Celia Cruz">
          Celia Cruz
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Cuba" title="Music of Cuba">
        Music of Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuban music is very rich and is the most commonly known expression of Cuban culture. The central form of this music is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Son_(music)" title="Son (music)">
        Son
       </a>
       , which has been the basis of many other musical styles like "
       <a href="/wiki/Danz%C3%B3n" title="Danzón">
        Danzón
       </a>
       de nuevo ritmo",
       <a href="/wiki/Mambo_(music)" title="Mambo (music)">
        mambo
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cha-cha-cha_(music)" title="Cha-cha-cha (music)">
        cha-cha-chá
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">
        salsa music
       </a>
       . Rumba ("de cajón o de solar") music originated in the early Afro-Cuban culture, mixed with Hispanic elements of style.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
        <a href="#cite_note-275">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tres_(musical_instrument)" title="Tres (musical instrument)">
        Tres
       </a>
       was invented in Cuba from Hispanic cordophone instruments models (the instrument is actually a fusion of elements from the Spanish guitar and lute). Other traditional Cuban instruments are of African origin,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-Ta%C3%ADno_nations" title="Neo-Taíno nations">
        Taíno
       </a>
       origin, or both, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Maraca" title="Maraca">
        maracas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCiro" title="Güiro">
        güiro
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADmbula" title="Marímbula">
        marímbula
       </a>
       and various wooden drums including the
       <a href="/wiki/Mayohuac%C3%A1n" title="Mayohuacán">
        mayohuacán
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Popular Cuban music of all styles has been enjoyed and praised widely across the world. Cuban classical music, which includes music with strong African and European influences, and features symphonic works as well as music for soloists, has received international acclaim thanks to composers like
       <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Lecuona" title="Ernesto Lecuona">
        Ernesto Lecuona
       </a>
       . Havana was the heart of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rap" title="Rap">
        rap
       </a>
       scene in Cuba when it began in the 1990s.
      </p>
      <p>
       During that time,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reggaet%C3%B3n" title="Reggaetón">
        reggaetón
       </a>
       was growing in popularity. In 2011, the Cuban state denounced reggaeton as degenerate, directed reduced "low-profile" airplay of the genre (but did not ban it entirely) and banned the megahit
       <i>
        Chupi Chupi
       </i>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Osmani_Garc%C3%ADa" title="Osmani García">
        Osmani García
       </a>
       , characterizing its description of sex as "the sort which a prostitute would carry out".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
        <a href="#cite_note-276">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In December 2012, the Cuban government officially banned sexually explicit reggaeton songs and music videos from radio and television.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As well as pop, classical and rock are very popular in Cuba.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_cuisine" title="Cuban cuisine">
        Cuban cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cubanfood.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Cubanfood.jpg/220px-Cubanfood.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Cubanfood.jpg/330px-Cubanfood.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Cubanfood.jpg/440px-Cubanfood.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cubanfood.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A traditional meal of
         <i>
          ropa vieja
         </i>
         (shredded flank steak in a tomato sauce base), black beans, yellow rice, plantains and fried yuca with beer
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_Havane_(1)_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4320" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg/220px-La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg/330px-La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg/440px-La_Havane_%281%29_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_Havane_(1)_Tamales_pli%C3%A9s.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cuban-style tamales
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuban cuisine is a fusion of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">
        Spanish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_cuisine" title="Caribbean cuisine">
        Caribbean cuisines
       </a>
       . Cuban recipes share spices and techniques with Spanish cooking, with some Caribbean influence in spice and flavor. Food rationing, which has been the norm in Cuba for the last four decades, restricts the common availability of these dishes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
        <a href="#cite_note-279">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The traditional Cuban meal is not served in courses; all food items are served at the same time.
      </p>
      <p>
       The typical meal could consist of plantains, black beans and rice,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ropa_vieja" title="Ropa vieja">
         ropa vieja
        </a>
       </i>
       (shredded beef),
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_bread" title="Cuban bread">
        Cuban bread
       </a>
       , pork with onions, and tropical fruits. Black beans and rice, referred to as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Moros_y_cristianos" title="Moros y cristianos">
         moros y cristianos
        </a>
       </i>
       (or
       <i>
        moros
       </i>
       for short), and plantains are staples of the Cuban diet. Many of the meat dishes are cooked slowly with light sauces. Garlic, cumin, oregano, and bay leaves are the dominant spices.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Cuban_literature" title="Cuban literature">
        Cuban literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuban literature began to find its voice in the early 19th century. Dominant themes of independence and freedom were exemplified by José Martí, who led the Modernist movement in Cuban literature. Writers such as
       <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Guill%C3%A9n" title="Nicolás Guillén">
        Nicolás Guillén
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jos%C3%A9_Z._Tallet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="José Z. Tallet (page does not exist)">
        José Z. Tallet
       </a>
       focused on literature as social protest. The poetry and novels of
       <a href="/wiki/Dulce_Mar%C3%ADa_Loynaz" title="Dulce María Loynaz">
        Dulce María Loynaz
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Lezama_Lima" title="José Lezama Lima">
        José Lezama Lima
       </a>
       have been influential. Romanticist
       <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Barnet" title="Miguel Barnet">
        Miguel Barnet
       </a>
       , who wrote
       <i>
        Everyone Dreamed of Cuba
       </i>
       , reflects a more melancholy Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Alejo_Carpentier" title="Alejo Carpentier">
        Alejo Carpentier
       </a>
       was important in the
       <a href="/wiki/Magic_realism" title="Magic realism">
        Magic realism
       </a>
       movement. Writers such as
       <a href="/wiki/Reinaldo_Arenas" title="Reinaldo Arenas">
        Reinaldo Arenas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Cabrera_Infante" title="Guillermo Cabrera Infante">
        Guillermo Cabrera Infante
       </a>
       , and more recently
       <a href="/wiki/Da%C3%ADna_Chaviano" title="Daína Chaviano">
        Daína Chaviano
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Juan_Guti%C3%A9rrez" title="Pedro Juan Gutiérrez">
        Pedro Juan Gutiérrez
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zo%C3%A9_Vald%C3%A9s" title="Zoé Valdés">
        Zoé Valdés
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Rosales" title="Guillermo Rosales">
        Guillermo Rosales
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonardo_Padura" title="Leonardo Padura">
        Leonardo Padura
       </a>
       have earned international recognition in the post-revolutionary era, though many of these writers have felt compelled to continue their work in exile due to ideological control of media by the Cuban authorities.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">
        Dance
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Dance holds a privileged position in Cuban culture.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Popular_dance" title="Popular dance">
        Popular dance
       </a>
       is considered an essential part of life, and
       <a href="/wiki/Concert_dance" title="Concert dance">
        concert dance
       </a>
       is supported by the government and includes internationally renowned companies such as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ballet_Nacional_de_Cuba" title="Ballet Nacional de Cuba">
        Ballet Nacional de Cuba
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnn_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Johnn-281">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Cuba" title="Sport in Cuba">
        Sport in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023,_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="536" data-file-width="400" height="295" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023%2C_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023%2C_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023%2C_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023%2C_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023%2C_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1985-1004-023,_Teofilo_Stevenson_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cuban former boxer
         <a href="/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Stevenson" title="Teófilo Stevenson">
          Teófilo Stevenson
         </a>
         , widely considered to be one of the greatest boxers of all time
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Due to historical associations with the United States, many Cubans participate in sports which are popular in North America, rather than sports traditionally promoted in other Latin American nations.
       <a href="/wiki/Baseball_in_Cuba" title="Baseball in Cuba">
        Baseball
       </a>
       is by far the most popular; other sports and pastimes include
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        football
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">
        basketball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
        volleyball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">
        cricket
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Track_and_field_athletics" title="Track and field athletics">
        athletics
       </a>
       . Cuba is a dominant force in
       <a href="/wiki/Amateur_boxing" title="Amateur boxing">
        amateur boxing
       </a>
       , consistently achieving high medal tallies in major international competitions. Cuban boxers are not permitted to turn professional by their government. However, many boxers defect to the U.S. and other countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba also provides a
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba_at_the_Olympics" title="Cuba at the Olympics">
        national team
       </a>
       that competes in the
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
        Olympic Games
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Cuba" title="Education in Cuba">
        Education in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg/220px-Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg/330px-Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg/440px-Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Universit%C3%A0_de_La_Habana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Havana" title="University of Havana">
          University of Havana
         </a>
         , founded in 1728
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Havana" title="University of Havana">
        University of Havana
       </a>
       was founded in 1728 and there are a number of other well-established
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Cuba" title="List of universities in Cuba">
        colleges and universities
       </a>
       . In 1957, just before Castro came to power, the literacy rate was fourth in the region at almost 80% according to the United Nations, higher than in Spain.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asce_91-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-asce-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Castro created an entirely state-operated system and banned private institutions. School attendance is compulsory from ages six to the end of basic secondary education (normally at age 15), and all students, regardless of age or gender, wear school uniforms with the color denoting grade level. Primary education lasts for six years, secondary education is divided into basic and pre-university education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-siteresources.worldbank.org_286-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-siteresources.worldbank.org-286">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">
        literacy rate
       </a>
       of 99.8 percent
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_202-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mdgs.un.org_287-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mdgs.un.org-287">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_literacy_rate" title="List of countries by literacy rate">
        tenth-highest globally
       </a>
       , due largely to the provision of free education at every level.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LiteracyC_288-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LiteracyC-288">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba's high school graduation rate is 94 percent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Higher education is provided by universities, higher institutes, higher
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pedagogical" title="Pedagogical">
        pedagogical
       </a>
       institutes, and higher
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_institutions_using_the_term_%22institute_of_technology%22_or_%22polytechnic%22" title='List of institutions using the term "institute of technology" or "polytechnic"'>
        polytechnic
       </a>
       institutes. The Cuban Ministry of Higher Education operates a scheme of distance education which provides regular afternoon and evening courses in rural areas for agricultural workers. Education has a strong political and ideological emphasis, and students progressing to higher education are expected to have a commitment to the goals of Cuba.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-siteresources.worldbank.org_286-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-siteresources.worldbank.org-286">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba has provided state subsidized education to a limited number of foreign nationals at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American_School_of_Medicine_(Cuba)" title="Latin American School of Medicine (Cuba)">
        Latin American School of Medicine
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Webometrics_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Webometrics Ranking of World Universities">
        Webometrics Ranking of World Universities
       </a>
       , the top-ranking universities in the country are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_de_la_Habana" title="Universidad de la Habana">
        Universidad de la Habana
       </a>
       (1680th worldwide),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Instituto_Superior_Polit%C3%A9cnico_Jos%C3%A9_Antonio_Echeverr%C3%ADa" title="Instituto Superior Politécnico José Antonio Echeverría">
        Instituto Superior Politécnico José Antonio Echeverría
       </a>
       (2893rd) and the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santiago_de_Cuba" title="University of Santiago de Cuba">
        University of Santiago de Cuba
       </a>
       (3831st).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Cuba" title="Healthcare in Cuba">
        Healthcare in Cuba
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Cuba's
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       at birth is 78.3 years (76.2 for males and 80.4 for females).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_202-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This ranks Cuba 55th in the world and 5th in the Americas, behind Canada, Chile, Costa Rica and the United States. Infant mortality declined from 32 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 1957, to 10 in 1990–95,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       6.1 in 2000–2005 and 5.13 in 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mdgs.un.org_287-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mdgs.un.org-287">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_202-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-factbook-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Historically, Cuba has ranked high in numbers of medical personnel and has made significant contributions to world health since the 19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asce_91-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-asce-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today, Cuba has
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
        universal health care
       </a>
       and despite persistent shortages of medical supplies, there is no shortage of medical personnel.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whiteford_294-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-whiteford-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Primary care is available throughout the island and infant and maternal mortality rates compare favorably with those in developed nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whiteford_294-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-whiteford-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Disease and infant mortality increased in the 1960s immediately after the revolution, when half of Cuba's 6,000 doctors left the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Recovery occurred by the 1980s,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bethell_79-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-bethell-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the country's health care has been widely praised.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feinsilver_1989_4to5_296-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Feinsilver_1989_4to5-296">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Communist government asserted that universal health care was a priority of state planning and progress was made in rural areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Like the rest of the
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Cuba" title="Economy of Cuba">
        Cuban economy
       </a>
       , medical care suffered from severe material shortages following the end of Soviet subsidies in 1991, and a tightening of the U.S. embargo in 1992.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Challenges include low salaries for doctors,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [299]
        </a>
       </sup>
       poor facilities, poor provision of equipment, and the frequent absence of essential drugs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuba has the highest doctor-to-population ratio in the world and has sent thousands of doctors to more than 40 countries around the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
        <a href="#cite_note-301">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">
        World Health Organization
       </a>
       , Cuba is "known the world over for its ability to train excellent doctors and nurses who can then go out to help other countries in need". As of September 2014, there are around 50,000 Cuban-trained health care workers aiding 66 nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
        <a href="#cite_note-302">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cuban physicians have played a leading role in combating the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ebola_virus_epidemic_in_West_Africa" title="Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa">
        Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Import and export of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_drug" title="Pharmaceutical drug">
        pharmaceutical drugs
       </a>
       is done by the Quimefa Pharmaceutical Business Group (FARMACUBA) under the Ministry of Basic Industry (MINBAS). This group also provides technical information for the production of these drugs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
        <a href="#cite_note-304">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Isolated from the West by the US embargo, Cuba developed the successful lung cancer vaccine,
       <a href="/wiki/CimaVax-EGF" title="CimaVax-EGF">
        Cimavax
       </a>
       , which is now available to US researchers for the first time, along with other novel Cuban cancer treatments. The vaccine has been available for free to the Cuban population since 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
        <a href="#cite_note-305">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roswell_Park_Cancer_Institute" title="Roswell Park Cancer Institute">
        Roswell Park Cancer Institute
       </a>
       CEO Candace Johnson: "They've had to do more with less, so they've had to be even more innovative with how they approach things. For over 40 years, they have had a preeminent immunology community."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2015, Cuba became the first country to eradicate
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother-to-child_transmission" title="Mother-to-child transmission">
        mother-to-child transmission
       </a>
       of HIV and syphilis,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
       a milestone hailed by the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">
        World Health Organization
       </a>
       as "one of the greatest public health achievements possible".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Graun_eradication_308-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Graun_eradication-308">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=National+symbols&amp;rft.pub=Government+of+Cuba&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmipais.cuba.cu%2Fcat_en.php%3Fidcat%3D91%26idpadre%3D83%26nivel%3D2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            ^

          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.jfklibrary.org/Research/Research-Aids/JFK-Speeches/Cincinnati-OH_19601006-Democratic-Dinner.aspx" rel="nofollow">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Remarks+of+Senator+John+F.+Kennedy+at+Democratic+Dinner%2C+Cincinnati%2C+Ohio&amp;rft.pub=John+F.+Kennedy+Presidential+Library+%26+Museum+%E2%80%93+Jfklibrary.org&amp;rft.date=1960-10-06&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jfklibrary.org%2FResearch%2FResearch-Aids%2FJFK-Speeches%2FCincinnati-OH_19601006-Democratic-Dinner.aspx&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-britannica-castro-16">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-britannica-castro_16-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Fidel-Castro" rel="nofollow">
            "Fidel Castro"
           </a>
           . Encyclopædia Britannica. 26 June 2017.
           <q>
            Castro created a one-party government to exercise dictatorial control over all aspects of Cuba's political, economic, and cultural life. All political dissent and opposition were ruthlessly suppressed
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Fidel+Castro&amp;rft.pub=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.date=2017-06-26&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fbiography%2FFidel-Castro&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-gonzalo-castro-17">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-gonzalo-castro_17-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-gonzalo-castro_17-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Fernández, Gonzalo (2009).
           <i>
            Cuba's Primer – Castro's Earring Economy
           </i>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780557065738" title="Special:BookSources/9780557065738">
            9780557065738
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            The number of individuals who have been jailed or deprived of their freedom in labor camps over the 50 years of Castro's dictatorship is estimated at around 200,000
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Cuba%27s+Primer+%E2%80%93+Castro%27s+Earring+Economy&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=9780557065738&amp;rft.aulast=Fern%C3%A1ndez&amp;rft.aufirst=Gonzalo&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-dw-castro-18">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-dw-castro_18-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.dw.com/en/fidel-castro-cubas-hero-and-dictator/a-36532751" rel="nofollow">

           </a>

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Fidel+Castro+%E2%80%93+Cuba%27s+hero+and+dictator&amp;rft.pub=Deutsche+Welle&amp;rft.date=2016-11-26&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dw.com%2Fen%2Ffidel-castro-cubas-hero-and-dictator%2Fa-36532751&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">

        <li id="cite_note-19">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-19">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Rangel, Carlos (1977).
           <i>
            The Latin Americans: Their Love-Hate Relationship with the United States
           </i>
           . New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. pp. 3–5.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-15-148795-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-15-148795-0">
            978-0-15-148795-0
           </a>
           .
          </cite>

          </b>

             2474886

            <img alt="Freely accessible" data-file-height="813" data-file-width="512" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/9px-Lock-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/14px-Lock-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/18px-Lock-green.svg.png 2x" title="Freely accessible" width="9"/>
           </span>
           .
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" title="PubMed Identifier">
            PMID
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18663207" rel="nofollow">
            18663207
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=CMAJ+%3A+Canadian+Medical+Association+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Health+consequences+of+Cuba%27s+Special+Period&amp;rft.volume=179&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=257&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2474886&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F18663207&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1503%2Fcmaj.1080068&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2474886&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">

           </a>
           . News.xinhuanet.com. June 4, 2009. Archived from

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=China+View+2009-06-04%3A+Cuba%27s+Fidel+Castro+calls+OAS+a+%22U.S.+Trojan+horse%22&amp;rft.pub=News.xinhuanet.com&amp;rft.date=2009-06-04&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.xinhuanet.com%2Fenglish%2F2009-06%2F04%2Fcontent_11485277.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>

        <li id="cite_note-125">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-125">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/16/world/americas/cuba-travel-policy/" rel="nofollow">
           CNN: "Cuba eases travel restriction for citizens" by Ben Brumfield
          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160304095615/http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/16/world/americas/cuba-travel-policy/" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          March 4, 2016, at the
          <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
           Wayback Machine
          </a>
          . 16 October 2012 |
          <i>
           Until now, Cubans had to pay $150 for an exit visa. A resident in the country that the Cuban wanted to visit would also have to write a letter of invitation. Fees associated with the letter ran as high as $200. That's a steep price in a country where the average official monthly income is about $20.
          </i>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-126">

          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161207180432/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-18933175" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          December 7, 2016, at the
          <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
           Wayback Machine
          </a>
          . 12 July 2012

        <li id="cite_note-133">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-133">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Andrea Mitchell; Eric McClam (December 18, 2014).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/u-s-cuba-relations/cuba-frees-american-alan-gross-held-five-years-n269926" rel="nofollow">

           </a>
           .
           <i>
            NBC News
           </i>
           .

          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://cpj.org/reports/2008/12/cpjs-2008-prison-census-online-and-in-jail.php" rel="nofollow">
            "CPJ's 2008 prison census: Online and in jail"
           </a>
           . Committee to Protect Journalists.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CPJ%27s+2008+prison+census%3A+Online+and+in+jail&amp;rft.pub=Committee+to+Protect+Journalists&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fcpj.org%2Freports%2F2008%2F12%2Fcpjs-2008-prison-census-online-and-in-jail.php&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-151">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           <a href="#cite_ref-151">
            ^

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=World+Report+2008%3A+Events+of+2007&amp;rft.pages=207&amp;rft.pub=Seven+Stories+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-58322-774-9&amp;rft.au=Human+Rights+Watch&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">

        <li id="cite_note-hrw1999-152">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-hrw1999_152-0">
           <sup>

             <b>
              a
             </b>

           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-hrw1999_152-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/cuba/Cuba996-05.htm" rel="nofollow">

           </a>

           <span class="reference-accessdate">

            <span class="nowrap">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Cuba%27s+Repressive+Machinery+%E2%80%93+V.+General+Prison+Conditions&amp;rft.pub=Human+Rights+Watch&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hrw.org%2Freports%2F1999%2Fcuba%2FCuba996-05.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-153">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-153">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10517497" rel="nofollow">
            "Number of Cuban political prisoners dips – rights group"
           </a>
           . BBC News. July 5, 2010
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             June 2,
            </span>
            2014
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Number+of+Cuban+political+prisoners+dips+%E2%80%93+rights+group&amp;rft.date=2010-07-05&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fnews%2F10517497&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_1996_159,161-154">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_1996_159,161_154-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses1996">
           Gleijeses 1996
          </a>
          , pp. 159, 161: "Cuba's relationship with Algeria in 1961–5 ... clashes with the image of Cuban foreign policy—cynical ploys of a [Soviet] client state—that prevails not only in the United States but also in many European capitals. ... The aid Cuba gave Algeria in 1961–2 had nothing to do with the East-West conflict. Its roots predate Castro's victory in 1959 and lie in the Cubans' widespread identification with the struggle of the Algerian people."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_2010_327-155">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_2010_327_155-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses2010">
           Gleijeses 2010
          </a>
          , p. 327: "The dispatch of 36,000 Cuban soldiers to Angola between November 1975 and April 1976 stunned the world; ... by 1988, there were 55,000 Cuban soldiers in Angola."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_2002_392-156">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_2002_392_156-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses2002">
           Gleijeses 2002
          </a>
          , p.
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QHWGwG71hzMC&amp;pg=PA392" rel="nofollow">
           392
          </a>
          : "After Angola, Cuba's largest military intervention was in Ethiopia, where in 1978 16,000 Cuban troops helped repulse the invading Somali army."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Tareke_2009_62to63-157">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Tareke_2009_62to63_157-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFTareke2009">
           Tareke 2009
          </a>
          , pp.
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=dRIfYPTZxJsC&amp;pg=PA62" rel="nofollow">
           62–3
          </a>
          . Tareke refers here to the training given to 10 members of the
          <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_Liberation_Front" title="Eritrean Liberation Front">
           Eritrean Liberation Front
          </a>
          in 1968 during the
          <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_War_of_Independence" title="Eritrean War of Independence">
           Eritrean struggle for independence
          </a>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_1997_50-158">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_1997_50_158-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses1997">
           Gleijeses 1997
          </a>
          , p. 50: "On 14–16 October 1960, [Guinean president Ahmed Sékou] Touré went to Havana. It was the first visit of an African chief of state to Cuba. The following year Cuba's foreign aid programme to Third World governments began when fifteen students from Guinea arrived in Havana to attend the university or technical institutes."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_1997_45-159">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_1997_45_159-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses1997">
           Gleijeses 1997
          </a>
          , p. 45: "Joining the rebellion in 1966, and remaining through the war's end in 1974, this was the longest Cuban intervention in Africa before the despatch of troops to Angola in November 1975. It was also the most successful. As the Guinean paper
          <i>
           Nõ Pintcha
          </i>
          declared, 'The Cubans' solidarity was decisive for our struggle
          <span style="padding-right:.2em;">
           '
          </span>
          ".
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Gleijeses_2002_227-160">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Gleijeses_2002_227_160-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGleijeses2002">
           Gleijeses 2002
          </a>
          , p.
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QHWGwG71hzMC&amp;pg=PA227&amp;dq=%22not+very+important%22" rel="nofollow">
           227
          </a>
          . The Cuban contribution to the independence of Mozambique was not very important.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTERamazani1975[https://books.google.com/books?id=7ETnbmUmxoUC&amp;pg=PA91_91]-161">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamazani1975[https://books.google.com/books?id=7ETnbmUmxoUC&amp;pg=PA91_91]_161-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRamazani1975">
           Ramazani 1975
          </a>
          , p.
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=7ETnbmUmxoUC&amp;pg=PA91" rel="nofollow">
           91
          </a>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Domínguez_1989_6-162">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Domínguez_1989_6_162-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFDomínguez1989">
           Domínguez 1989
          </a>
          , p. 6: "Cuba is a small country, but it has the foreign policy of a big power."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Feinsilver_1989_2-163">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Feinsilver_1989_2_163-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFFeinsilver1989">
           Feinsilver 1989
          </a>
          , p. 2: "Cuba has projected disproportionately greater power and influence through military might ... through economic largesse ... as a mediator in regional conflicts, and as a forceful and persuasive advocate of Third World interests in international forums. Cuba's scientific achievements, while limited, are also being shared with other Third World countries, thereby furthering Cuban influence and prestige abroad."
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-164">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <li id="cite_note-167">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-167">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Millman, Joel (January 15, 2011).
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203731004576045640711118766" rel="nofollow">
            "New Prize in Cold War: Cuban Doctors"
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">
            wsj.com
           </a>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             April 24,
            </span>
            2013
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=New+Prize+in+Cold+War%3A+Cuban+Doctors&amp;rft.pub=wsj.com&amp;rft.date=2011-01-15&amp;rft.aulast=Millman&amp;rft.aufirst=Joel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wsj.com%2Farticles%2FSB10001424052970203731004576045640711118766&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-168">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-168">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Arsenault, Chris (December 31, 2012).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/venezuelaelection/2012/10/20121039242915607.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Cuban doctors prescribe hope in Venezuela"
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/Al_Jazeera_English" title="Al Jazeera English">
            aljazeera.com
           </a>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             April 24,
            </span>
            2013
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Cuban+doctors+prescribe+hope+in+Venezuela&amp;rft.pub=aljazeera.com&amp;rft.date=2012-12-31&amp;rft.aulast=Arsenault&amp;rft.aufirst=Chris&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aljazeera.com%2Findepth%2Fspotlight%2Fvenezuelaelection%2F2012%2F10%2F20121039242915607.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <br/>
          As the article discusses, the oil-for-doctors programme has not been welcomed uncritically in Venezuela. The initial impetus for Cuban doctors' going to Venezuela was a Chavez-government welfare project called
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Mission_Barrio_Adentro" title="Mission Barrio Adentro">
            Misión Barrio Adentro
           </a>
          </i>
          (
          <a href="#CITEREFAlbornoz2006">
           Albornoz 2006
          </a>
          ).
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-169">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-169">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRoy2000">
           Roy 2000
          </a>
          .
          <br/>
          Roy's study was described as "systematic and fair" by
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jorge_I._Dominguez" title="Jorge I. Dominguez">
           Jorge Domínguez
          </a>
          —see
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Domínguez, Jorge I. (2001). "Reviews:
           <i>
            Cuba, the United States, and the Helms-Burton Doctrine: International Reactions
           </i>
           by Joaquín Roy".
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Journal_of_Latin_American_Studies" title="Journal of Latin American Studies">
             Journal of Latin American Studies
            </a>
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            33
           </b>
           (4): 888–890.
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1017%2Fs0022216x0133626x" rel="nofollow">
            10.1017/s0022216x0133626x
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/JSTOR" title="JSTOR">
            JSTOR
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3653779" rel="nofollow">
            3653779
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Latin+American+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Reviews%3A+Cuba%2C+the+United+States%2C+and+the+Helms-Burton+Doctrine%3A+International+Reactions+by+Joaqu%C3%ADn+Roy&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=888-890&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2Fs0022216x0133626x&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F3653779&amp;rft.aulast=Dom%C3%ADnguez&amp;rft.aufirst=Jorge+I.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-170">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-170">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110511102350/http://ec.europa.eu/development/icenter/repository/EU-Cuba-Joint%20declaration-261108_EN.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "Joint declarations concerning areas and modalities provisionally identified for cooperation"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           . European Commission. November 26, 2008. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/development/icenter/repository/EU-Cuba-Joint%20declaration-261108_EN.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           on May 11, 2011
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             September 6,
            </span>
            2009
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Joint+declarations+concerning+areas+and+modalities+provisionally+identified+for+cooperation&amp;rft.pub=European+Commission&amp;rft.date=2008-11-26&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fec.europa.eu%2Fdevelopment%2Ficenter%2Frepository%2FEU-Cuba-Joint%2520declaration-261108_EN.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

           .
          </cite>

         <span class="reference-text">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Cuban+immigration&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+North+American+Immigration&amp;rft.pages=68-71&amp;rft.pub=Facts+on+File&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.aulast=Powell&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DVNCX6UsdZYkC%26pg%3DPA68%26dq%3D%2522cubans%2Bare%2Busually%2Bconsidered%2Bto%2Bbe%2Bthe%2Bmost%2Bsuccessful%2522%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DX%26ved%3D0ahUKEwjemvHQhdHQAhXogFQKHf-FAYsQ6AEIIDAA%23v%3Donepage%26q%3D%2522cubans%2520are%2520usually%2520considered%2520to%2520be%2520the%2520most%2520successful%2522%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Pedraza_2007_?-252">

        <li id="cite_note-295">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-295">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <i>
           Cuba: A Different America
          </i>
          , By Wilber A. Chaffee, Gary Prevost, Rowland and Littlefield, 1992, p. 106
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-Feinsilver_1989_4to5-296">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Feinsilver_1989_4to5_296-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFFeinsilver1989">
           Feinsilver 1989
          </a>
          , pp. 4–5: "Its success has been acclaimed by Dr. Halfdan Mahler, the Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO), and Dr. Carlysle Guerra de Macedo, Director-General of the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO), as well as by medical professionals from the United States and other capitalist countries who have observed the Cuban health system in action. Despite U.S. hostility toward Cuba, a U.S. government document stated in 1982 that the 'Cuban Revolution has managed social achievements, especially in education and health care, that are highly respected in the Third World ..., [including] a national health care program that is superior in the Third World and rivals that of numerous developed countries.
          <span style="padding-right:.2em;">
           '
          </span>
          "
         </span>
        </li>

           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=theguardian.com&amp;rft.atitle=Cuba+first+to+eliminate+mother-to-baby+HIV+transmission&amp;rft.date=2015-06-30&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Carroll&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsociety%2F2015%2Fjun%2F30%2Fcuba-first-eliminate-mother-baby-hiv-transmission&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACuba">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>

          <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Cuba" title="c:Special:Search/Cuba">
           Media
          </a>
          from Wikimedia Commons
         </span>
        </li>
        <li style="min-height: 31px;">
         <span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;">

         </span>

        <tr>
         <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
          <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Caribbean" title="History of the Caribbean">
           History
          </a>
         </th>
         <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
          <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
          </div>
          <table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0">
           <tr>
            <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:6.5em;padding-left:0.5em;padding-right:0.5em;font-weight:normal;">
             Timeline
            </th>
            <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;padding:0px">
             <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
              <ul>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Taíno">
                 Taíno
                </a>
                –
                <a href="/wiki/Arawak" title="Arawak">
                 Arawak
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Spanish_West_Indies" title="Spanish West Indies">
                 Spanish Caribbean (1492–1898)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_Antilles" title="Netherlands Antilles">
                 Dutch Caribbean (1554–1863)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_British_West_Indies" title="History of the British West Indies">
                 British Caribbean (1586–1834)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/French_West_Indies" title="French West Indies">
                 French Caribbean (1625–1817)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Couronian_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Couronian colonization of the Americas">
                 Baltic-German Caribbean (1654-1689)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Danish_West_Indies" title="Danish West Indies">
                 Danish Caribbean (1672–1917)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Saint_Thomas_(Brandenburg_colony)" title="Saint Thomas (Brandenburg colony)">
                 German Caribbean (1685-1693)
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Swedish_colony_of_Saint_Barth%C3%A9lemy" title="Swedish colony of Saint Barthélemy">
                 Swedish Caribbean (1784–1878)
                </a>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>

                       </small>
                      </li>
                     </ul>
                    </li>
                   </ul>
                  </div>
                 </td>
                </tr>

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh-yue">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://zh-yue.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%8F%A4%E5%B7%B4" hreflang="zh-yue" lang="zh-yue" title="古巴 – Cantonese">
         粵語
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-diq">

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zea">

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-bat-smg">

        </a>

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh">

        </a>
